description: ISO/IEC 20000:2011 is the International Standard for IT service management. In this accredited show we explore the requirements for an organization to achieve the ISO/IEC 20000 certification. This show is designed as a 1st step for managers and internal auditors who are considering gaining accreditation for their organization and as an overview for IT staff who’s organization is working towards accreditation. This show will also prepare individuals for the ISO/IEC 20000 examination.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:03.050
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.050 --> 00:00:07.120
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco

3
00:00:07.120 --> 00:00:08.354
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:08.354 --> 00:00:11.931
>> Welcome to your ISO/IEC

5
00:00:11.931 --> 00:00:18.900
20000:2011 Foundation series.

6
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:21.050
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:21.050 --> 00:00:25.400
In this episode, we have ISO
expert Jo Peacock to come in and

8
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:28.840
introduce what the series
is really all about.

9
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:30.060
So, thank you for joining us today, Jo.

10
00:00:30.060 --> 00:00:31.000
How are you doing?

11
00:00:31.000 --> 00:00:34.740
>> Well, I'm doing fine, but
I want to help you out right now, okay?

12
00:00:34.740 --> 00:00:37.150
Because that's quite a bit of a mouthful,
isn't it?

13
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:38.000
>> It was a mouthful.

14
00:00:38.000 --> 00:00:40.000
>> Yeah, ISO, ICE.

15
00:00:40.000 --> 00:00:44.110
20000 2011, yeah let's call it ISO 20k,
how about that?

16
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:44.610
>> Okay.

17
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:46.770
>> Even ISO 20000.

18
00:00:46.770 --> 00:00:51.670
We should really technically
use the right terminology for

19
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:55.500
this because it is an international
standard so it's the, it's for

20
00:00:55.500 --> 00:00:58.840
the, from the international
organization for standardization.

21
00:00:58.840 --> 00:01:02.010
But however we're just
gonna call it ISO 20000.

22
00:01:02.010 --> 00:01:04.920
>> Yeah, I mean this is
a technical show anyways, so

23
00:01:04.920 --> 00:01:07.820
let's be technical at least once per show.

24
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:08.630
How about that?

25
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:10.580
>> Right, yeah,
we should do that once per show.

26
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:11.910
But nevertheless-
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:11.910 --> 00:01:13.790
>> We know that this is a lot for

28
00:01:13.790 --> 00:01:15.290
everybody to get their mouths around.

29
00:01:15.290 --> 00:01:18.330
And for those of you that
are trying to achieve ISO 20000,

30
00:01:18.330 --> 00:01:20.440
then you're gonna be calling it ISO 20000.

31
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:24.540
You're certainly not gonna be banding
that around the office all the time.

32
00:01:24.540 --> 00:01:26.405
>> We have enough to think about, right?

33
00:01:26.405 --> 00:01:29.510
>> [LAUGH] So yeah,
I'm doing fine anyway, how are you?

34
00:01:29.510 --> 00:01:30.300
>> I'm good.

35
00:01:30.300 --> 00:01:35.290
So who are we really focusing this
training for, or these shows for?

36
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:37.730
Who should be interested in
watching these shows, Jo?

37
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:41.270
>> Well, the first thing that I want to do
is just explain a little bit about what

38
00:01:41.270 --> 00:01:43.159
ISO 20,000 is.

39
00:01:43.159 --> 00:01:45.470
>> Okay.
>> And then in this particular episode,

40
00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:50.070
I'm just going to give us just
general overview of who should

41
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:54.050
actually be interested in this show and
who should sort of sit and

42
00:01:54.050 --> 00:01:55.880
watch some of the episodes in this show.

43
00:01:55.880 --> 00:01:56.840
Okay?

44
00:01:56.840 --> 00:02:00.500
So the first thing that I wanna do
as I've said is just to highlight

45
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:02.341
what ISO 20,000 is.

46
00:02:02.341 --> 00:02:06.520
ISO 20,000 is
the international standard for

47
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:11.340
IT service management,
all right what does that mean and

48
00:02:11.340 --> 00:02:14.430
how does it differ from ITIL
because we've got shows about ITIL.

49
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:17.160
And of course there's been a lot of

50
00:02:17.160 --> 00:02:21.340
talk about ITIL around the world
in the past few years.

51
00:02:21.340 --> 00:02:24.980
Well ITIL is just a framework
it is a framework for

52
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:28.842
managing IT services and
it's at best practice frame work.

53
00:02:30.050 --> 00:02:31.990
But there is no audit for ITIL.

54
00:02:31.990 --> 00:02:35.860
There's nobody that can come in and tell
you whether you're doing ITIL right or

55
00:02:35.860 --> 00:02:41.820
wrong because ITIL is a framework that
you bring into your organization.

56
00:02:41.820 --> 00:02:43.400
You adopt the framework.

57
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:47.570
But then you adapt it in a way
that makes common sense,

58
00:02:47.570 --> 00:02:50.190
perfect sense for your organization.

59
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:55.520
So you adapt it for efficiency and for
effectiveness in your organization.

60
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:57.010
ITIL is not plug and play.

61
00:02:57.010 --> 00:03:01.080
ITIL is not a one-size-fits-all approach
that will solve all of the world's

62
00:03:01.080 --> 00:03:01.650
problems.

63
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:03.960
Common misconception there.

64
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:05.745
You know,
ITIL's gonna do everything right.

65
00:03:05.745 --> 00:03:09.140
[LAUGH] Well, ITIL doesn't do that.

66
00:03:09.140 --> 00:03:12.250
ITIL is, as I said, just the framework.

67
00:03:12.250 --> 00:03:15.010
We won't tell you what your
processes will look like.

68
00:03:15.010 --> 00:03:16.630
We'll tell you that you
need to have a process.

69
00:03:16.630 --> 00:03:22.590
And we'll tell you how to in I-Tel,
how to define a process as well.

70
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:27.940
So we'll tell you that you need to have
a process for restoring service operation.

71
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:31.930
In other words, for getting people back up
and running when something's gone wrong.

72
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:36.770
And in I-Tel In ITIL mind we
call this incident management.

73
00:03:36.770 --> 00:03:40.380
And so
we'll tell you that you need to work out

74
00:03:40.380 --> 00:03:43.260
what incident management looks like for
your organization.

75
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:48.515
So you will need to have
a process to restore service.

76
00:03:48.515 --> 00:03:51.635
When it goes wrong,
to get it back up and running again.

77
00:03:51.635 --> 00:03:55.955
And so what ITIL does is ITIL says to
you okay, you need to have this process.

78
00:03:55.955 --> 00:04:01.355
Here's some,
I was gonna say hints and tips.

79
00:04:01.355 --> 00:04:05.545
Here's some very useful information that's
going to help you define a process.

80
00:04:06.570 --> 00:04:11.220
Will tell you that you start by working
at what your process should do.

81
00:04:11.220 --> 00:04:15.640
Work at its objective and
then work out the output from the process.

82
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:18.980
So what should the output
from a process look like?

83
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:20.560
Then what about the inputs?

84
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:22.740
The various inputs to a process.

85
00:04:22.740 --> 00:04:27.640
And then, okay, what steps do you need
in your organization to ensure that

86
00:04:27.640 --> 00:04:29.580
we get from the inputs to the outputs.

87
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:32.145
And this is what ITIL will tell you.

88
00:04:32.145 --> 00:04:35.770
ITIL will tell you not only what
processes you should have, but

89
00:04:35.770 --> 00:04:38.770
also how to define those processes.

90
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:43.250
But we won't tell you what your
processes look like, not in ITIL.

91
00:04:43.250 --> 00:04:45.790
So there can't be an audit for ITIL.

92
00:04:45.790 --> 00:04:47.775
Nobody can come along, even me.

93
00:04:47.775 --> 00:04:48.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

94
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:52.640
I like to think of myself as fairly
knowledgeable on the subject.

95
00:04:52.640 --> 00:04:57.460
So I can't come along and say,
yes, that's working great for

96
00:04:57.460 --> 00:04:59.950
your organization using the checklist.

97
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:02.160
I can't do that.

98
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:04.694
I can't audit you from here.

99
00:05:06.950 --> 00:05:09.160
There is no iTel compliance.

100
00:05:10.370 --> 00:05:14.070
And this is something that's a common
misconception amongst everybody that tries

101
00:05:14.070 --> 00:05:17.490
to implement ITIL,
is that you can be ITIL compliant.

102
00:05:17.490 --> 00:05:21.490
And you can't be ITIL compliant,
cuz there's no right or wrong with ITIL.

103
00:05:23.400 --> 00:05:26.130
So, The question that I ask is though,

104
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:28.730
what's the difference between ITIL and
ISO 20000.

105
00:05:28.730 --> 00:05:31.350
Well, that's what ITIL is.

106
00:05:31.350 --> 00:05:33.400
ITIL's a framework for managing services,

107
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:37.155
it's the best practice framework that
you adapt to sync your organization.

108
00:05:37.155 --> 00:05:40.235
So how do you know if
it's working okay then?

109
00:05:40.235 --> 00:05:43.025
How do you know if ITIL is working great?

110
00:05:43.025 --> 00:05:45.915
Well when we have something
that's completely independent,

111
00:05:45.915 --> 00:05:47.545
completely separate.

112
00:05:47.545 --> 00:05:49.665
Has absolutely nothing to do with ITIL.

113
00:05:49.665 --> 00:05:53.775
I say that with a wink all right.

114
00:05:53.775 --> 00:05:57.270
Has absolutely nothing to
do with ITIL whatsoever.

115
00:05:57.270 --> 00:06:01.030
We have an international standard for
service management,

116
00:06:01.030 --> 00:06:02.900
for IT service management.

117
00:06:04.460 --> 00:06:06.010
And with any international standard,

118
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:08.765
an international standard is
something that you attain.

119
00:06:08.765 --> 00:06:11.879
It's something that you achieve,

120
00:06:11.879 --> 00:06:16.987
it's something that you can
say that you can comply with.

121
00:06:16.987 --> 00:06:21.740
ISO 20,000 is a standard,

122
00:06:21.740 --> 00:06:27.240
where you can measure yourself against and
it's a standard for

123
00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:32.950
demonstrating efficiency and
effectiveness and

124
00:06:32.950 --> 00:06:40.170
the relationships in place between
IT service management processes.

125
00:06:40.170 --> 00:06:45.370
So, it's a standard for demonstrating

126
00:06:45.370 --> 00:06:50.550
that you are able to
manage your IT services

127
00:06:50.550 --> 00:06:56.259
in a way that is the most efficient and
effective for your organization.

128
00:06:57.410 --> 00:07:01.600
So it's a standard where
you are audited against

129
00:07:03.170 --> 00:07:07.800
your processes and your services,
to ensure that your processes and

130
00:07:07.800 --> 00:07:11.530
services are delivering
value to your organization,

131
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:16.170
that you have the right processes
in place in order to achieve this.

132
00:07:16.170 --> 00:07:21.260
But also, and when I say achieve this
I mean achieve value delivery, but

133
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:25.510
also that those processes work
efficiently and effectively.

134
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:29.840
That they're not bound down by
bureaucracy, that they're actually

135
00:07:29.840 --> 00:07:33.760
working in a way that will deliver
the most value to your organization.

136
00:07:35.770 --> 00:07:40.280
So ISO 20000 does not audit ITIL.

137
00:07:40.280 --> 00:07:42.280
This is not an ITIL audit.

138
00:07:43.290 --> 00:07:46.990
ITIL is just a best practice framework,
and there are lots of other frameworks.

139
00:07:46.990 --> 00:07:49.440
Even proprietary frameworks
that are out there.

140
00:07:49.440 --> 00:07:54.378
There are a lot of organizations
that have created proprietary

141
00:07:54.378 --> 00:07:56.527
frameworks for instance.

142
00:07:56.527 --> 00:07:57.385
And of course,

143
00:07:57.385 --> 00:08:01.610
what you evolve in your organization
becomes your proprietary framework.

144
00:08:01.610 --> 00:08:06.690
Now your proprietary management
framework will achieve ISO 20000,

145
00:08:06.690 --> 00:08:09.700
as long as it is efficient and

146
00:08:09.700 --> 00:08:15.210
it is effective in the processes and
the way that IT is managed.

147
00:08:16.290 --> 00:08:20.050
So there is a big
difference between the two.

148
00:08:20.050 --> 00:08:26.200
ISO 20000 is a standard for
the management of services.

149
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:31.700
Now, if you have implemented ITIL in
a way that is the best practice for

150
00:08:31.700 --> 00:08:37.539
your organization, then that will
help you to achieve ISO 20000.

151
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:41.391
I am not gonna tell you that
if you got ITIL implemented,

152
00:08:41.391 --> 00:08:44.130
then you're definitely
going to achieve ISO 20000.

153
00:08:44.130 --> 00:08:45.898
Cuz that's not the case.

154
00:08:45.898 --> 00:08:51.030
Cuz if you've got an ITIL framework
implemented in your organization.

155
00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:56.820
Then unless you have modified and
adapted that ITIL framework in a way that

156
00:08:56.820 --> 00:09:01.530
is the most efficient for you, then you're
not going to achieve ISO 20000 at all.

157
00:09:02.580 --> 00:09:08.760
You will only achieve ISO 20000 if
you can meet all of the requirements

158
00:09:08.760 --> 00:09:13.960
that are outlined in the ISO 20000,
we call them parts.

159
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:19.080
So these are the requirements
of ISO 20000.

160
00:09:19.080 --> 00:09:23.350
So ISO 20000, as I've said,
is something that you achieve.

161
00:09:24.860 --> 00:09:30.830
And it is something that you will have
an auditor come to your organization.

162
00:09:30.830 --> 00:09:34.630
And this is after you've had a lot of
time to prepare for this, by the way.

163
00:09:34.630 --> 00:09:40.350
And an auditor will look at your
processes and look at your environment.

164
00:09:40.350 --> 00:09:45.320
And look at the tools and
the management that you have in place, and

165
00:09:45.320 --> 00:09:46.720
the way that you work.

166
00:09:46.720 --> 00:09:51.070
And we'll assess whether you
have achieved all of the clauses

167
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:53.650
within the ISO 20000 requirement.

168
00:09:55.520 --> 00:10:01.500
So ISO 20000, as I've said,
is not dependent on ITIL at all.

169
00:10:01.500 --> 00:10:05.720
However, if you have an ITIL based
framework in place, and it's working

170
00:10:05.720 --> 00:10:10.840
efficiently and effectively, then it will
certainly help you to achieve ISO 20000.

171
00:10:10.840 --> 00:10:12.702
Cherokee, you have a question.

172
00:10:12.702 --> 00:10:16.745
>> Yeah, Jo, I know you've taught some
pretty high level courses here ITProTV.

173
00:10:16.745 --> 00:10:18.807
And just looking at the title for
this one,

174
00:10:18.807 --> 00:10:21.570
you're talking about the auditing process.

175
00:10:21.570 --> 00:10:23.666
Now this course that
we're about to get into,

176
00:10:23.666 --> 00:10:26.427
this isn't one that will prepare
us to be auditors, per se.

177
00:10:26.427 --> 00:10:30.147
But looking at the foundations, we want to
get a good understanding in order to be

178
00:10:30.147 --> 00:10:33.145
able to facilitate this implementation,
correct?

179
00:10:33.145 --> 00:10:37.560
>> Right, so what this course will do
is this course will prepare you for.

180
00:10:37.560 --> 00:10:40.530
>> It will tell you all about
the requirements for an ISO 20000 audit,

181
00:10:40.530 --> 00:10:41.555
as it were.

182
00:10:41.555 --> 00:10:42.880
Okay.

183
00:10:42.880 --> 00:10:44.280
So we use this course.

184
00:10:44.280 --> 00:10:47.790
And in fact, on this particular slide
that we've got in front of us now.

185
00:10:47.790 --> 00:10:51.170
We use this course,
just take a look at the target audience.

186
00:10:51.170 --> 00:10:56.636
We would use this course to prepare
people for an audit for ISO 20000.

187
00:10:56.636 --> 00:10:59.940
Perfect.
A lot of organizations will implement

188
00:10:59.940 --> 00:11:01.440
an ITIL based framework.

189
00:11:01.440 --> 00:11:05.240
And I won't say ITIL based framework,
cuz you never implement ITIL.

190
00:11:05.240 --> 00:11:07.380
You always implement ITIL based.

191
00:11:07.380 --> 00:11:11.990
And so what will happen is, organizations
get to a point where they perceive

192
00:11:11.990 --> 00:11:16.650
that they have implemented this framework,
and that it's working, great.

193
00:11:16.650 --> 00:11:19.100
And that they are working efficiently and
effectively.

194
00:11:19.100 --> 00:11:20.930
And so what do we do now, then?

195
00:11:20.930 --> 00:11:23.320
We can't demonstrate ITIL compliance.

196
00:11:23.320 --> 00:11:24.080
So what do we do?

197
00:11:24.080 --> 00:11:26.730
We wanna have that certificate,
we wanna have that plaque on the wall.

198
00:11:26.730 --> 00:11:28.282
>> Yeah, we wanna get some kind of.

199
00:11:28.282 --> 00:11:29.340
Recognition.
Recognition for

200
00:11:29.340 --> 00:11:31.290
our hard work that we've
put into everything.

201
00:11:31.290 --> 00:11:34.870
>> Right, and so
why the target audience for this is for

202
00:11:34.870 --> 00:11:39.210
those organizations that are saying,
okay, I wanna get some recognition now.

203
00:11:39.210 --> 00:11:40.720
How do I do this?

204
00:11:40.720 --> 00:11:45.850
And so it's at this point in time where an
organization might look for recognition,

205
00:11:45.850 --> 00:11:50.850
and the first place that they will come
to is the international standards.

206
00:11:50.850 --> 00:11:55.690
And your international standard,
your ISO 20000, will actually give them

207
00:11:55.690 --> 00:11:59.550
recognition for having a service
management framework in place.

208
00:11:59.550 --> 00:12:01.160
Not necessarily ITIL.

209
00:12:01.160 --> 00:12:03.900
But it's a management framework that

210
00:12:03.900 --> 00:12:09.610
will promote the delivery of
value to the business, itself.

211
00:12:09.610 --> 00:12:11.260
So the target audience for

212
00:12:11.260 --> 00:12:16.270
this are all those people who are going
to be involved in an ISO 20000 audit.

213
00:12:16.270 --> 00:12:20.330
So all of those people that
are preparing for an ISO 20000 audit.

214
00:12:20.330 --> 00:12:24.350
These are all of those people that
are gonna be involved in the actual

215
00:12:24.350 --> 00:12:25.980
audit process.

216
00:12:25.980 --> 00:12:28.890
And all of those people within IT.

217
00:12:28.890 --> 00:12:31.660
And it says here in that second
bullet point down underneath it,

218
00:12:31.660 --> 00:12:32.650
the target audience.

219
00:12:32.650 --> 00:12:35.790
It says managers,
team leaders, and other staff.

220
00:12:35.790 --> 00:12:38.675
>> Right, because I don't think it's
just isolated to the IT department.

221
00:12:38.675 --> 00:12:41.790
Those other stakeholders should
at least understand what

222
00:12:41.790 --> 00:12:44.530
they're approaching before the audit,
right?

223
00:12:44.530 --> 00:12:46.090
>> The biggest misconception for

224
00:12:46.090 --> 00:12:51.050
ISO 20000 is that we're just going to let
all the managers know what's going on.

225
00:12:51.050 --> 00:12:54.480
And as far as letting everybody else know,

00:06:10.022 --> 00:06:12.760

We've got to ensure

00:06:23.930 --> 00:06:27.251

00:07:30.850 --> 00:07:33.060

00:08:29.831 --> 00:08:34.838

00:08:41.640 --> 00:08:43.740

142
00:08:59.190 --> 00:09:04.434

143

145
00:09:11.440 --> 00:09:13.325
And so exactly the same with this.

146
00:09:13.325 --> 00:09:19.470
We have ISO 27002, that doesn't
mean that ISO 27001 is redundant.

147
00:09:20.530 --> 00:09:24.870
Using the UK version of the word
redundant, so obsolete, all right?

148
00:09:24.870 --> 00:09:29.890
It's not obsolete, it just means
that we have now a newer version.

00:09:29.890 --> 00:09:34.846

00:09:34.846 --> 00:09:38.640

00:09:38.640 --> 00:09:39.550

152
00:09:39.550 --> 00:09:42.220
These are all input into our
service management system.

153
00:09:43.610 --> 00:09:48.340

00:09:48.340 --> 00:09:55.620

00:10:00.150 --> 00:10:01.350

157
00:10:01.350 --> 00:10:03.570
Whether they want to
achieve those standards.

158
00:10:03.570 --> 00:10:08.989
That's not something that would
be a regulatory requirement.

00:10:08.989 --> 00:10:14.359

00:10:14.359 --> 00:10:17.620

>> I'm trying to think-

the most part organization-

And about the International Standard here
ISO 20000, is that with both ISO 20000 and

389
00:25:54.550 --> 00:25:59.760
with ISO 27002 as well, we have

390
00:26:00.840 --> 00:26:05.720
a number of what we would
call related publications.

391
00:26:05.720 --> 00:26:10.351
We have a number of complementary
publications that are out there in the big

392
00:26:10.351 --> 00:26:12.863
wide world, that can help us with this.

393
00:26:12.863 --> 00:26:17.487
We've got guides to ISO 20000-1.

394
00:26:17.487 --> 00:26:20.245
We've got guides to
service management itself,

395
00:26:20.245 --> 00:26:25.172
we've got self-assessment workbooks, etc.,
that are available out there in the big

396
00:26:25.172 --> 00:26:28.670
wide world,
that can help us achieve all of this.

397
00:26:28.670 --> 00:26:32.310
There's also ITIL, and
ITIL as a service management framework,

398
00:26:32.310 --> 00:26:34.370
that will help us achieve.

399
00:26:34.370 --> 00:26:36.280
None of these we guarantee by the way,

400
00:26:36.280 --> 00:26:40.120
that you're going to achieve
ISO 20000 certification.

401
00:26:40.120 --> 00:26:44.440
But they're all going to help,
along with other frameworks,

402
00:26:44.440 --> 00:26:48.270
such as COBIT, and CMMI,
and project management too.

403
00:26:48.270 --> 00:26:52.331
>> So these are all just a small search
away, small Internet search away from us?

404
00:26:52.331 --> 00:26:56.300
>> Yes, yeah, yeah, and all of this
is available at our fingertips.

405
00:26:56.300 --> 00:26:59.055
We don't leave you sort of
flaming around in the dark,

406
00:26:59.055 --> 00:27:02.530
[LAUGH] we want to help you achieve this.

407
00:27:02.530 --> 00:27:05.860
But we have to make sure that
we maintain the standard.

408
00:27:05.860 --> 00:27:10.160
So we know that the standard is
quite difficult to maintain.

409
00:27:10.160 --> 00:27:11.570
So we wanna help you, but

410
00:27:11.570 --> 00:27:15.270
we also want to ensure that it
is kept as a standard as well.

411
00:27:16.420 --> 00:27:21.634
So in terms of part one, then in terms
of international standard itself,

412
00:27:21.634 --> 00:27:24.335
this is what part one like looks like.

413
00:27:24.335 --> 00:27:26.623
These are the contents of part one.

414
00:27:26.623 --> 00:27:31.168
And the contents of part one talk about
our scope, and our references, and

415
00:27:31.168 --> 00:27:33.235
our terms and definitions.

416
00:27:33.235 --> 00:27:37.595
We look in clause four,
at the service management system, and

417
00:27:37.595 --> 00:27:41.615
what the management responsibility is,
and how we govern processes.

418
00:27:41.615 --> 00:27:46.765
In clause five, we look at how we
design and transition our new services.

419
00:27:46.765 --> 00:27:50.265
And then in clause six,
we look at our delivery processes,

420
00:27:50.265 --> 00:27:54.710
such as service level management,
and reporting, and continuity.

421
00:27:55.750 --> 00:27:59.010
In clause seven,
we look at relationship processes.

422
00:27:59.010 --> 00:28:02.070
In clause eight,
we look at resolution processes.

423
00:28:02.070 --> 00:28:05.500
And in clause nine,
we look at control processes.

424
00:28:05.500 --> 00:28:08.150
Now, a few things that
I want to point out on

425
00:28:08.150 --> 00:28:10.700
this particular slide that's
in front of us right now.

426
00:28:11.760 --> 00:28:16.160
There are some things that look very
very similar to those of you that have

427
00:28:16.160 --> 00:28:19.920
completed an ITIL class, there are some
things that look incredibly similar.

428
00:28:19.920 --> 00:28:23.050
But you'll notice that in our
service delivery processes,

429
00:28:23.050 --> 00:28:28.060
reporting is actually a process,
and certainly not in ITIL.

430
00:28:28.060 --> 00:28:30.560
You'll notice that in our
resolution processes,

431
00:28:30.560 --> 00:28:33.300
service request management is in there.

432
00:28:33.300 --> 00:28:37.400
And yet, hang on, didn't we have
a request fulfillment in ITIL?

433
00:28:38.530 --> 00:28:40.570
It's called something
completely different,

434
00:28:40.570 --> 00:28:42.560
because we're resolving a request.

435
00:28:43.610 --> 00:28:46.235
So be careful, be very very careful.

436
00:28:46.235 --> 00:28:51.500
And I know that I've said this
before in previous episodes,

437
00:28:51.500 --> 00:28:57.385
but be very careful about
the understanding of bringing in terms and

438
00:28:57.385 --> 00:29:01.326
definitions from ITIL into ISO 20000.

439
00:29:01.326 --> 00:29:02.670
That's something that we don't wanna do.

440
00:29:02.670 --> 00:29:05.890
We don't want to confuse that, okay.

441
00:29:05.890 --> 00:29:10.418
Let's take a look, then,
at some terms and definitions,

442
00:29:10.418 --> 00:29:14.867
very briefly,
that are associated with ISO 20000.

443
00:29:14.867 --> 00:29:16.818
A service provider is somebody,

444
00:29:16.818 --> 00:29:20.099
an organization that delivers
services to customers.

445
00:29:21.440 --> 00:29:23.646
Now, look at the definition of a service,
and

446
00:29:23.646 --> 00:29:26.087
compare that to the definition
of an ITIL service.

447
00:29:26.087 --> 00:29:31.288
The definition of a service here within
ISO 20000 is a means of delivering value

448
00:29:31.288 --> 00:29:36.210
for a customer, by facilitating the
results that a customer wants to achieve.

449
00:29:37.300 --> 00:29:41.260
Very similar to the ITIL definition
of a service, but not quite the same.

450
00:29:42.340 --> 00:29:46.880
And then we have a service component,
which is a unit of a service.

451
00:29:46.880 --> 00:29:50.080
That when combined with our other units,
deliver a complete service.

452
00:29:50.080 --> 00:29:54.170
You might have called that
a configuration item in ITIL.

453
00:29:54.170 --> 00:29:55.930
And then we've got an interested party.

454
00:29:55.930 --> 00:30:01.780
And an interested party is what we might
have called a stakeholder, within ITIL.

455
00:30:01.780 --> 00:30:06.450
But in interested parties, anybody that is
interested, in either the performance or

456
00:30:06.450 --> 00:30:10.590
the success of service
provider activities.

457
00:30:12.930 --> 00:30:16.190
So think about who our
interested parties might be.

458
00:30:16.190 --> 00:30:19.060
Our interested parties,
to us, could be customers or

459
00:30:19.060 --> 00:30:23.830
internal, groups, or suppliers, or
a customer who is acting as a supplier.

460
00:30:23.830 --> 00:30:29.747
Maybe think about shared services
in this particular instance.

461
00:30:29.747 --> 00:30:31.257
Let's think about HR.

462
00:30:31.257 --> 00:30:36.270
HR is a customer of ours in IT, but
they also act as a supplier to us as well.

463
00:30:36.270 --> 00:30:41.430
Because they give us information in
terms of security profiling, for

464
00:30:41.430 --> 00:30:43.060
instance, for our users.

465
00:30:43.060 --> 00:30:45.210
And then, of course, we have our users.

466
00:30:45.210 --> 00:30:47.600
Now, Cherokee,
I'm gonna ask you a question right now.

467
00:30:48.620 --> 00:30:52.657
Do you remember what the difference
between a customer and a user is?

468
00:30:52.657 --> 00:30:53.532
>> I do, Jo.

469
00:30:53.532 --> 00:30:54.408
>> Woo!

470
00:30:54.408 --> 00:30:55.328
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So,

471
00:30:55.328 --> 00:30:58.364
would you like to [CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah, yeah.

472
00:30:58.364 --> 00:30:59.324
Okay, come on tell me.

473
00:30:59.324 --> 00:31:03.185
>> So your customer,
let's start with a customer, so

474
00:31:03.185 --> 00:31:08.210
your customer is going to be someone
who is paying for this service.

475
00:31:08.210 --> 00:31:13.573
Whereas your user may be someone
who is accessing a free trial,

476
00:31:13.573 --> 00:31:16.820
or the customer has paid for the user.

477
00:31:18.370 --> 00:31:23.830
So like maybe, if my company was paying
for my training here at ITProTV.

478
00:31:23.830 --> 00:31:25.850
So the company could be the customer,

479
00:31:25.850 --> 00:31:29.010
whereas the employee,
me, I would be the user.

480
00:31:29.010 --> 00:31:30.579
So?

481
00:31:30.579 --> 00:31:32.031
>> We got there.

482
00:31:32.031 --> 00:31:32.982
>> You got there.

483
00:31:32.982 --> 00:31:34.796
>> Yeah, we got there.
>> A long way there,

484
00:31:34.796 --> 00:31:35.830
but-
>> [LAUGH] yeah,

485
00:31:35.830 --> 00:31:37.760
a customer is somebody who pays.

486
00:31:37.760 --> 00:31:39.078
Think of a call center manager,

487
00:31:39.078 --> 00:31:43.740
they're a customer, and
a user is somebody who uses the service.

488
00:31:43.740 --> 00:31:44.580
Simple as that.

489
00:31:44.580 --> 00:31:46.450
They could be one and the same thing.

490
00:31:46.450 --> 00:31:50.600
>> Yeah, it could be a user that is also
a customer, I pay for it independently.

491
00:31:51.680 --> 00:31:54.790
>> It's not about independently,
but all customers are users.

492
00:31:54.790 --> 00:31:57.369
Even all call center managers
will still use the service.

493
00:31:58.760 --> 00:32:00.570
So customers could still be users.

494
00:32:00.570 --> 00:32:02.548
Customers could be somebody senior,

495
00:32:02.548 --> 00:32:05.343
who don't necessarily use
the service themselves.

496
00:32:05.343 --> 00:32:06.751
>> Not user, just customer.

497
00:32:06.751 --> 00:32:08.416
>> Yeah, I always like to
think about Starbucks right-

498
00:32:08.416 --> 00:32:10.112
>> [LAUGH]

499
00:32:10.112 --> 00:32:11.538
>> At this point in time.

500
00:32:11.538 --> 00:32:13.640
>> Yeah, that's a good analogy
that you shared before.

501
00:32:13.640 --> 00:32:16.650
>> Yeah,
I always like to think about Starbucks.

502
00:32:16.650 --> 00:32:19.980
If I were to take you into Starbucks and

503
00:32:19.980 --> 00:32:24.060
buy you a drink, then I would be
the customer, and you would be the user.

504
00:32:25.270 --> 00:32:29.669
What I'm concerned about as
a customer is that that cup's full.

505
00:32:29.669 --> 00:32:31.650
I wanna get value for money.

506
00:32:31.650 --> 00:32:34.521
What you're concerned about as a user is?

507
00:32:34.521 --> 00:32:35.342
>> Delicious.

508
00:32:35.342 --> 00:32:36.416
>> Yeah, she wants it to taste good.

509
00:32:36.416 --> 00:32:39.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> She's gonna influence me.

510
00:32:39.670 --> 00:32:44.490
Because if she doesn't like it as a user,
the next time I say come on, let's go for

511
00:32:44.490 --> 00:32:46.130
a coffee, you're gonna?

512
00:32:46.130 --> 00:32:47.077
>> We're going to Opus.

513
00:32:47.077 --> 00:32:48.709
>> Right, we're going somewhere else.

514
00:32:48.709 --> 00:32:52.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so users influence customers.

515
00:32:52.620 --> 00:32:57.010
But I could also be a user as well, cuz I
could actually buy a coffee, not just for

516
00:32:57.010 --> 00:32:59.500
Cherokee, but I could get myself one too.

517
00:32:59.500 --> 00:33:03.090
In which case then I'm fulfilling a role
of both the customer and the user.

518
00:33:03.090 --> 00:33:03.890
>> Exactly.

519
00:33:03.890 --> 00:33:07.587
>> Yeah, so customers and
users, they are different.

520
00:33:07.587 --> 00:33:11.413
And it's at this point in time,
where I think it's appropriate for

521
00:33:11.413 --> 00:33:12.493
us to take a break.

522
00:33:12.493 --> 00:33:14.979
>> Sounds like a good idea Jo, but-
>> Cuz I want coffee.

523
00:33:14.979 --> 00:33:16.248
I don't know about anybody else.

524
00:33:16.248 --> 00:33:18.349
>> I know, you got us thinking
about all this coffee now.

525
00:33:18.349 --> 00:33:20.833
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we're not quite finished yet Jo.

526
00:33:20.833 --> 00:33:23.781
So thank you for sharing that
information with us, and thank you for

527
00:33:23.781 --> 00:33:25.040
being here as well.

528
00:33:25.040 --> 00:33:27.040
But stay tuned we have
more headed your way.

529
00:33:27.040 --> 00:33:28.630
For this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

530
00:33:28.630 --> 00:33:29.960
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

531
00:33:29.960 --> 00:33:30.790
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

532
00:33:30.790 --> 00:33:33.202
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

533
00:33:33.202 --> 00:33:39.047
[MUSIC]

534
00:33:39.047 --> 00:33:42.418
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue to explain the ISO 2000 standard. First, Jo defines the contents of a scope. She then shares an example of a supply chain and explains what  the ISO clauses are.   Jo also explains the certification process and breaks down roles of the National Accreditation Bodies (NABs), Registered Certified Bodies (RCBs)  and more.
episodes.title: Standard Overview Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.662
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.662 --> 00:00:06.712
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.712 --> 00:00:08.298
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.298 --> 00:00:13.611
>> You're watching, ITProTV
>> Welcome, ladies and gentlemen

5
00:00:13.611 --> 00:00:21.300
to your ISO/IEC 20000:2011 Foundation
series I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:21.300 --> 00:00:25.920
In this episode, we'll continue with the
part three, where we examine the overview.

7
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:30.100
And here, back in studios with us today,
we have expert, Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:30.973
How's it going today, Jo?

9
00:00:30.973 --> 00:00:32.817
>> Absolutely great,
how are you, Cherokee?

10
00:00:32.817 --> 00:00:35.135
>> I'm doing lovely, thank you for asking.

11
00:00:35.135 --> 00:00:38.622
So I know we've already covered
information in a part one and a part two.

12
00:00:38.622 --> 00:00:40.264
What could be left?

13
00:00:40.264 --> 00:00:46.890
>> Okay, we're just gonna carry on with
just our overview really of ISO 20000.

14
00:00:46.890 --> 00:00:49.399
I call it ISO 20000 by the way,

15
00:00:49.399 --> 00:00:54.850
it makes it a lot easier than ISO
stroke IEC 20000 2011, all right?

16
00:00:54.850 --> 00:00:56.023
>> I know, I'll get this eventually guys.

17
00:00:56.023 --> 00:00:59.483
>> You noticed how I always
leave you the with the long.

18
00:00:59.483 --> 00:01:00.900
>> The job, yeah, that's okay.

19
00:01:00.900 --> 00:01:03.240
>> That's okay, I'm happy with that.

20
00:01:03.240 --> 00:01:06.900
So we're just gonna carry on
with the Overview of ISO 20000.

21
00:01:06.900 --> 00:01:12.170
We're going to look at
a sample scope of an audit,

22
00:01:12.170 --> 00:01:18.030
and we're also then going to just look
at the accreditation process, itself.

23
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:20.470
So just a very, very brief overview, but

24
00:01:20.470 --> 00:01:22.510
we'll just carry on
really where we left off.

25
00:01:22.510 --> 00:01:24.544
As you already said, this is a part three.

26
00:01:24.544 --> 00:01:27.500
So let's launch straight into this.

27
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:30.230
And the first thing that I want
to talk to you about really,

28
00:01:30.230 --> 00:01:35.610
is the fact that we already touched on
this in the last, in our last episode.

29
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:40.014
When we talked about working in that
siloed mentality, if you remember.

30
00:01:40.014 --> 00:01:45.289
Well, what we want to do is make sure
that we have a defined scope for

31
00:01:45.289 --> 00:01:51.640
our audit itself, or our assessment
against the ISO 20000 standard.

32
00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:56.206
Because you can actually work in silos,
you can audit in silos.

33
00:01:56.206 --> 00:01:59.726
You could audit within,
if you are a service provider for

34
00:01:59.726 --> 00:02:01.424
a specific business unit.

35
00:02:01.424 --> 00:02:06.017
You could audit just on that one
particular service provider for

36
00:02:06.017 --> 00:02:08.800
that individual business unit.

37
00:02:08.800 --> 00:02:14.320
Or you could audit on the entire IT
service provider organization in itself.

38
00:02:15.480 --> 00:02:17.739
Why is that so important?

39
00:02:17.739 --> 00:02:22.325
Well, the reason why this is
particularly important is because for

40
00:02:22.325 --> 00:02:24.160
large organization.

41
00:02:24.160 --> 00:02:28.280
The larger the scale of the organization,
in other words the bigger the organization

42
00:02:28.280 --> 00:02:33.400
is, the more likely you
want to want to try and

43
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:36.860
audit certain parts of your
service provider organization.

44
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:43.241
If you are trying to achieve
an audit at ISO 20000 for

45
00:02:43.241 --> 00:02:47.651
your whole entire IT service
provider organization.

46
00:02:47.651 --> 00:02:51.819
But then, you run the risk of,
maybe, it might be too generic, or

47
00:02:51.819 --> 00:02:54.880
maybe you might be looking
at certain elements.

48
00:02:54.880 --> 00:02:58.850
Certain mandatory requirements that you
simply just can't achieve right away,

49
00:02:58.850 --> 00:03:00.030
across the board.

50
00:03:00.030 --> 00:03:05.160
You can achieve certain requirements
in specific business units,

51
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:08.280
but you can't achieve them
right away across the board.

52
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:12.880
So there are a number of reasons why
we need you to define the scope.

53
00:03:12.880 --> 00:03:18.160
The scope is not automatically just IT,
okay?

54
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:22.427
That's your first misconception
that I need you to get over,

55
00:03:22.427 --> 00:03:25.228
is that you have got to tell the auditor.

56
00:03:25.228 --> 00:03:30.210
You have got to tell
the accreditation board what

57
00:03:30.210 --> 00:03:35.010
it is that you are going to be auditing.

58
00:03:35.010 --> 00:03:40.160
In other words, what teams, what processes
are going to fall under your audit.

59
00:03:40.160 --> 00:03:43.530
And so the first thing that you
have to do is define a scope.

60
00:03:44.540 --> 00:03:49.182
And so the scope statement that you define
has gotta be agreed with your auditor in

61
00:03:49.182 --> 00:03:49.805
advance.

62
00:03:49.805 --> 00:03:54.435
When you make an application
to an accreditation board to

63
00:03:54.435 --> 00:03:59.070
undertake an audit,
an auditor will be assigned to you.

64
00:03:59.070 --> 00:04:04.024
You will be put in contact with
an auditor, and it's at that point in time

65
00:04:04.024 --> 00:04:09.130
where you agree with the auditor
what the scope of the audit will be.

66
00:04:09.130 --> 00:04:12.740
Now it includes things like the name
of the organization and the scope.

67
00:04:12.740 --> 00:04:15.910
What services are going to be audited,
what processes,

68
00:04:15.910 --> 00:04:17.770
what interfaces are going to be audited.

69
00:04:18.810 --> 00:04:21.520
It may also, and
we'll definitely advise this, but

70
00:04:21.520 --> 00:04:25.750
it may also include some of the location
of the actual service provider.

71
00:04:25.750 --> 00:04:30.470
Because it may be that you want
to audit one particular location,

72
00:04:30.470 --> 00:04:34.440
but other geographical locations,
you might not want to audit.

73
00:04:34.440 --> 00:04:38.230
Let's think about those
organizations where, for instance,

74
00:04:38.230 --> 00:04:43.130
second and third level is done in-house,
but maybe our service desk is outsourced.

75
00:04:43.130 --> 00:04:46.800
And our service desk is
outsourced to another provider,

76
00:04:46.800 --> 00:04:49.420
who maybe in a different
geographical location.

77
00:04:49.420 --> 00:04:52.120
Maybe around the other side of the world,
for instance.

78
00:04:52.120 --> 00:04:56.480
So you may want to specify that
the scope does not include that.

79
00:04:58.460 --> 00:05:01.040
So also think about who the customer is.

80
00:05:01.040 --> 00:05:04.950
You may want to, if you are auditing for
a specific service, for

81
00:05:04.950 --> 00:05:08.200
a specific customer,
you may want to specify that.

82
00:05:08.200 --> 00:05:13.699
You may even want to specify within your
scope the technology that you're using.

83

536
00:32:42.170 --> 00:32:44.960
It's a recommendation for
improvement, it's non-compulsory.

537
00:32:44.960 --> 00:32:47.750
And something that we deem to be
outside the scope of the audit,

538
00:32:47.750 --> 00:32:50.150
well that's something that
doesn't need to be audited.

539
00:32:50.150 --> 00:32:54.410
But any nonconformities Well,
nonconformities are a failure.

540
00:32:54.410 --> 00:32:58.170
We need to ensure that
the nonconformities are worked on.

541
00:32:59.210 --> 00:33:04.130
So which is why I always tell you I'd
always recommend to have an internal audit

542
00:33:04.130 --> 00:33:09.320
or maybe to get another auditor And
other consultants come in,

543
00:33:09.320 --> 00:33:13.420
and to actually work
with you before you get

544
00:33:13.420 --> 00:33:17.770
the actual auditor themselves coming
in and doing the audit for you.

545
00:33:17.770 --> 00:33:20.530
Because you don't want to
have any nonconformities.

546
00:33:20.530 --> 00:33:22.790
You certainly don't want
a major nonconformity.

547
00:33:22.790 --> 00:33:27.400
And even the minor nonconformities,
you wanna make sure they're gonna give you

548
00:33:27.400 --> 00:33:31.150
opportunity to actually rectify that and
to put something in place, but

549
00:33:31.150 --> 00:33:33.780
you've got to make sure that you're
in the position to do that as well.

550
00:33:35.000 --> 00:33:39.640
So, at this point in time, what we've
actually covered is, we've done a lot of,

551
00:33:39.640 --> 00:33:43.170
we've covered a lot of the sort
of pre-requisites, as it were,

552
00:33:43.170 --> 00:33:44.920
to the standard itself.

553
00:33:44.920 --> 00:33:47.340
Just a general overview of the standard.

554
00:33:47.340 --> 00:33:50.300
And on our next episode,
what we're going to take a look

555
00:33:50.300 --> 00:33:52.590
at is we're starting to
take a look at the clauses,

556
00:33:52.590 --> 00:33:58.450
clauses four through to clauses
nine in part one of ISO 20000.

557
00:33:58.450 --> 00:34:02.730
So we'll start off with clause four,
which is our service management system.

558
00:34:02.730 --> 00:34:03.740
>> All right, sounds like a plan.

559
00:34:03.740 --> 00:34:06.300
We've got some SMS headed your way,
so stay tuned for that.

560
00:34:06.300 --> 00:34:09.290
But for this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

561
00:34:09.290 --> 00:34:10.880
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

562
00:34:10.880 --> 00:34:11.706
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

563
00:34:11.706 --> 00:34:13.002
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

564
00:34:13.002 --> 00:34:20.019
[MUSIC]

565
00:34:20.019 --> 00:34:22.010
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain what a  Service Management System is. The ladies cover what should be included within the SMS and explain that the service provider is responsible for continual improvement of the SMS. In addition to the "shalls" Jo also defines roles, the governance of processes, an example process model in and more!

57

And we're coming closer

75

So here we have here again this plan

we keep our customers happy.

81

We have policies and
we have objectives for service management,

82
00:05:11.954 --> 00:05:15.935
that we can use then to

83

Now one thing that we haven't really
touched on here, and to be perfectly

honest, in ISO 20000, because it's very,
very difficult for us to audit for this.

85
00:05:26.182 --> 00:05:30.292
We will audit for
relationship processes, but

86
00:05:30.292 --> 00:05:35.437
we have to be very aware of
the fact that value is perceived.

87
00:05:35.437 --> 00:05:39.657
And so when we talk about
delivering value to our customers.

88
00:05:39.657 --> 00:05:44.152
Well, we have to be able to demonstrate
that we deliver value to our customers.

00:05:44.152 --> 00:05:48.868
Which means that we've got to have

90
00:05:48.868 --> 00:05:51.493
Because we've gotta
demonstrate value to them so

00:05:51.493 --> 00:05:55.760
we have to understand what they

We have to be able to monitor

00:06:00.360 --> 00:06:04.890
We have to be able to monitor our

00:06:04.890 --> 00:06:08.290
And we have to be able to demonstrate
that they are delivering value,

95
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:12.250
and that they're subject

96
00:06:12.250 --> 00:06:16.970
Not continuous, but continual, which

97
00:06:16.970 --> 00:06:22.057
It's a continual,
it's a iterative method of improvement.

98
00:06:22.057 --> 00:06:24.461
What we want to do is as we've said,

relationships with our customers.

100
00:06:28.481 --> 00:06:33.316
Cuz we've got to demonstrate

101
00:06:33.316 --> 00:06:37.099
we have to have good
relationships with them.

102
00:06:37.099 --> 00:06:42.031
Now we have a definition that

00:06:42.031 --> 00:06:45.661
that's the definition of top management,
or

104
00:06:45.661 --> 00:06:49.774
senior management,

105
00:06:49.774 --> 00:06:52.975
And our senior management,
or top management,

106
00:06:52.975 --> 00:06:57.580
are the people that are responsible for
not only defining the SMS, but

107
00:06:57.580 --> 00:07:00.719
also for maintaining and

108
00:07:00.719 --> 00:07:05.774
Our SMS, our service management system,

00:07:05.774 --> 00:07:10.830
refers to all of the policies and
the principles, the objectives,

110
00:07:10.830 --> 00:07:15.177
and the processes that we put
into place in order manage and

00:07:19.282 --> 00:07:22.517
So we have to take

00:07:22.517 --> 00:07:26.975
We have to consider the entire service

00:07:46.144 --> 00:07:48.275

00:07:48.275 --> 00:07:51.225
And we also have to demonstrate,
and I'm gonna

use that word a lot when it talks about

00:07:56.166 --> 00:08:01.440
if you want to achieve ISO 20000

00:08:01.440 --> 00:08:07.449

That you are actually performing all

00:08:07.449 --> 00:08:13.004

00:08:13.004 --> 00:08:15.930
You have to articulate this.

126
00:08:15.930 --> 00:08:17.217
You have to demonstrate.

127
00:08:17.217 --> 00:08:19.896
I like to use words like, show me.

00:08:19.896 --> 00:08:23.670
And that also means that in order

00:08:23.670 --> 00:08:27.230

00:08:27.230 --> 00:08:29.889
I talked about having capabilities

00:08:29.889 --> 00:08:35.152
And again, we've gotta demonstrate,

00:08:35.152 --> 00:08:40.645

133
00:08:40.645 --> 00:08:45.285
So we have to show we've got the right

00:08:45.285 --> 00:08:47.045

135
00:08:48.525 --> 00:08:50.645
So your SMS, it's another tool.

There are toolsets that can help you with

00:08:56.435 --> 00:08:57.620
of itself.

138
00:08:57.620 --> 00:09:01.655
And it consists of a policy,

139
00:09:01.655 --> 00:09:04.000
It consist of an organizational chart,

140
00:09:04.000 --> 00:09:07.110
these are the people with
a defined responsibility.

141
00:09:07.110 --> 00:09:12.060
And it consists of processes,
processes that themselves have policies.

142
00:09:12.060 --> 00:09:17.130
Processes that require planning,
processes that actually perform planning.

143
00:09:17.130 --> 00:09:19.170
Processes that perform implementation,

144
00:09:19.170 --> 00:09:22.890

145
00:09:22.890 --> 00:09:27.280
Processes that assess our services to

146
00:09:27.280 --> 00:09:29.180
the needs of the organization.

147
00:09:29.180 --> 00:09:34.310
And processes that highlight
implementation of improvements for

148
00:09:34.310 --> 00:09:37.210

149
00:09:37.210 --> 00:09:41.920
So our SMS, our service management system,
is not just about a tool.

150
00:09:42.980 --> 00:09:45.960
And it's not even just
about the documentation.

151
00:09:45.960 --> 00:09:48.220
It's also about the people as well.

152
00:09:48.220 --> 00:09:53.316
Everything that we need to
manage our IT services.

153
00:09:53.316 --> 00:09:59.849
The service management system is
a structured framework, as it says there.

154
00:09:59.849 --> 00:10:05.590
And this is where you can have
that confusion with ITIL.

155
00:10:05.590 --> 00:10:09.870
ITIL is a framework for
cert managing services, a framework for

156
00:10:09.870 --> 00:10:11.020
service management.

157
00:10:11.020 --> 00:10:13.440
It's a best practice framework for
service management and

158
00:10:13.440 --> 00:10:17.900
it is not a one size fits all approach,
okay?

159
00:10:17.900 --> 00:10:22.187
It's not,
it's something that you have to adapt.

160
00:10:22.187 --> 00:10:24.200
ISO 20000 is a standard.

161
00:10:24.200 --> 00:10:29.060
It's something that you have to achieve.

162
00:10:29.060 --> 00:10:34.080
You implement ITIL, but
you achieve ISO 20000, okay?

163
00:10:34.080 --> 00:10:35.643
It's a check in the box.

164
00:10:35.643 --> 00:10:40.572
It's a certificate on the wall
to say that yes, I've got and

165
00:10:40.572 --> 00:10:46.190
an efficient and effective service
management framework in place.

166
00:10:47.200 --> 00:10:50.850
And this SMS is what we use
to govern that framework.

167
00:10:50.850 --> 00:10:53.790
The SMS ensures that we
have a framework in place.

168
00:10:55.210 --> 00:10:58.060
And it also ensures that we are subject to

169
00:10:58.060 --> 00:11:00.840
continual improvement
within that framework.

170
00:11:01.870 --> 00:11:04.900
So it means having defined roles,
as we've already said,

171
00:11:04.900 --> 00:11:07.410
and defined responsibilities.

172
00:11:07.410 --> 00:11:13.090
With everybody having the relevant
capability to be able to do their role.

173
00:11:13.090 --> 00:11:17.880
And if we have an SMS in place,
and if we are working towards and

174
00:11:17.880 --> 00:11:21.668
have achieved ISO 20000,
then the customers have got

175
00:11:21.668 --> 00:11:26.190
an assurance of quality service provision.

176
00:11:26.190 --> 00:11:32.610
In other words, they are assured
that we are working in a consistent,

177
00:11:32.610 --> 00:11:39.830
and in an efficient and effective manner,
to enable us to deliver value to them.

178
00:11:41.240 --> 00:11:44.490
So we've got some definitions
here on this next slide.

179
00:11:44.490 --> 00:11:47.720
And our definitions are just things
that we've already talked about,

180
00:11:47.720 --> 00:11:48.430
top management.

181
00:11:48.430 --> 00:11:51.650
These are the people that
control the service provider.

182
00:11:51.650 --> 00:11:53.174
So these are our senior management.

183
00:11:53.174 --> 00:11:56.710
Continual improvement,
as opposed to continuous.

184
00:11:56.710 --> 00:11:59.360
Continual means iterative improvement.

185
00:11:59.360 --> 00:12:05.080
Then we have corrective action,
that's something that we undertake.

186
00:12:05.080 --> 00:12:09.851
And these terms, you will find these
in your downloadable material as well

187
00:12:09.851 --> 00:12:12.890
that accompanies these
particular episodes.

188
00:12:12.890 --> 00:12:14.183
Corrective action,

189
00:12:14.183 --> 00:12:18.577
that's something that we do in order
to put something right basically.

190
00:12:18.577 --> 00:12:22.103
And as it says,
either we'll eliminate the cause or

191
00:12:22.103 --> 00:12:27.320
reduce the likelihood of a nonconformity
within in our audit process.

192
00:12:27.320 --> 00:12:28.840
And preventive action,

193
00:12:28.840 --> 00:12:33.930
well, that's action that we take to try
and prevent something from happening.

194
00:12:33.930 --> 00:12:36.770
Corrective action is something
that we take to pick up the pieces

195
00:12:36.770 --> 00:12:38.300
after something's happened.

424
00:28:00.890 --> 00:28:08.360
the resources to manage all of these
components in our Part 1, in our Shall.

425
00:28:08.360 --> 00:28:10.960
And that means all of
the technical resources.

426
00:28:10.960 --> 00:28:11.990
It means our relation-
>> Right,

427
00:28:11.990 --> 00:28:13.550
what are you doing to
save these documents?

428
00:28:13.550 --> 00:28:16.780
Are you using SharePoint, are you using
a cloud provider, so all of that.

429
00:28:16.780 --> 00:28:17.450
>> Right.

430
00:28:17.450 --> 00:28:22.350
Yeah, and in fact, now we've even got,
very, very recently, in fact,

431
00:28:22.350 --> 00:28:25.820
in just about 18 months ago now.

432
00:28:25.820 --> 00:28:29.460
There was a new part
released to ISO 20000,

433
00:28:29.460 --> 00:28:33.820
which actually specifically
covered cloud computing.

434
00:28:33.820 --> 00:28:36.410
>> Interesting.
>> And how this applies to using

435
00:28:36.410 --> 00:28:38.980
cloud as an external provider.

436
00:28:38.980 --> 00:28:41.515
Because a lot of organizations
nowadays are using cloud.

437
00:28:41.515 --> 00:28:44.400
We don't always have,
unfortunately we don't always have

438
00:28:46.650 --> 00:28:48.710
sort of the relevant skills in house.

439
00:28:48.710 --> 00:28:52.970
And we don't need to anymore,
because it's an expensive thing to do.

440
00:28:52.970 --> 00:28:56.350
So when we talk about our resources,

441
00:28:56.350 --> 00:29:02.650
we talk about our external resources,
those that are externally managed as well.

442
00:29:02.650 --> 00:29:08.380
So we have to demonstrate that the people
that we have as well are competent.

443
00:29:08.380 --> 00:29:12.620
That they've got the appropriate skills,
and that they have got the appropriate

444
00:29:12.620 --> 00:29:16.490
training, and that they've got
the experience, etc., as well.

445
00:29:16.490 --> 00:29:21.040
And so we have to make sure that we,
again, I'm saying, show me.

446
00:29:21.040 --> 00:29:24.860
In part 1, I'm always saying, show me.

447
00:29:24.860 --> 00:29:27.850
This is [LAUGH] what I
say a lot to people.

448
00:29:27.850 --> 00:29:31.390
So when it comes to people,
I will say, show me.

449
00:29:31.390 --> 00:29:32.860
Show me exactly what you've got.

450
00:29:32.860 --> 00:29:34.910
Show me that you've got skill matrices.

451
00:29:34.910 --> 00:29:38.170
Show me that you're doing regular
performance reviews with these people.

452
00:29:38.170 --> 00:29:41.630
Show me that you have evidence and
job descriptions, etc.

453
00:29:41.630 --> 00:29:46.160
And that the people
are actually able to fulfill

454
00:29:46.160 --> 00:29:49.750
all of the service requirements
that you have on your service.

455
00:29:51.340 --> 00:29:55.870
Ultimately, we've got to make sure that
we work with the customer to continually

456
00:29:57.145 --> 00:30:02.945
improve our services to continually
provide services that our customers need.

457
00:30:02.945 --> 00:30:10.765
So if I look here at the responsibility
here of establishing the SMS,

458
00:30:10.765 --> 00:30:15.875
we've got to ensure that we improve
the SMS on a regular basis as well.

459
00:30:17.050 --> 00:30:19.060
So at this point in time,

460
00:30:19.060 --> 00:30:23.770
what I'm actually going to say is that
we have reached the end of Part 1.

461
00:30:23.770 --> 00:30:26.080
>> Okay.
>> Of looking at the SMS,

462
00:30:26.080 --> 00:30:28.520
because I know that we've
had a lot of information.

463
00:30:28.520 --> 00:30:33.010
But don't forget, when we look at the SMS
what we're looking at it, what we're

464
00:30:33.010 --> 00:30:38.640
going to be auditing for, what we're going
to be checking that you have in place,

465
00:30:38.640 --> 00:30:43.810
I don't expect to see one tool
with all of this information.

466
00:30:43.810 --> 00:30:49.780
What I expect to see is that you have
a hierarchy of management in place.

467
00:30:49.780 --> 00:30:54.670
That when I say to you, show me,
you can say, okay, yes.

468
00:30:54.670 --> 00:30:56.240
It's in this tool here.

469
00:30:56.240 --> 00:31:01.380
This is how I access it, and this is
the evidence that you're asking for.

470
00:31:01.380 --> 00:31:03.580
That's what I expect to see.

471
00:31:03.580 --> 00:31:06.780
I don't expect you to have
something called an SMS.

472
00:31:08.140 --> 00:31:13.818
I expect you to have the tools at your
finger tips to be able to show me.

473
00:31:13.818 --> 00:31:15.625
>> All right, Jo.

474
00:31:15.625 --> 00:31:19.620
So if we ever get in that situation,
then we should know what to expect then.

475
00:31:19.620 --> 00:31:20.685
Jo wants to see that.

476
00:31:20.685 --> 00:31:23.085
The auditors,
they want to see that, right?

477
00:31:23.085 --> 00:31:24.875
So thank you for
providing that information, but

478
00:31:24.875 --> 00:31:26.845
I know you said we have
more to cover here.

479
00:31:26.845 --> 00:31:31.255
So, ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned for
that, but for this show we will sign out.

480
00:31:31.255 --> 00:31:32.775
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

481
00:31:32.775 --> 00:31:33.675
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

482
00:31:33.675 --> 00:31:35.600
>> See you next time here at ITProTV

483
00:31:35.600 --> 00:31:42.126
[MUSIC]

484
00:31:42.126 --> 00:31:45.129
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue to cover the SMS. In line with the PDCA or deeming cycle the ladies encourage thought on the cyclic process.  They talk about improving the SMS and what type of considerations may help with planning.
episodes.title: Clause 4 - Service Management System Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.856
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.856 --> 00:00:05.859
We're coming at you live from
San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:05.859 --> 00:00:08.420
>> [CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.420 --> 00:00:11.841
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.841 --> 00:00:18.579
>> Welcome back to your ISO/IEC
20000: 2011 Foundation series.

6
00:00:18.579 --> 00:00:20.700
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:23.430
In this episode,
we'll pick right back up with a part two,

8
00:00:23.430 --> 00:00:27.430
where we're really looking
at Clause 4 with our SMS.

9
00:00:27.430 --> 00:00:30.497
And back with us today in studios
we have expert Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.497 --> 00:00:31.650
How are you doing today, Jo?

11
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:33.360
>> I'm doing absolutely great,
thank you Cherokee.

12
00:00:33.360 --> 00:00:34.020
How are you?

13
00:00:34.020 --> 00:00:36.080
>> I'm doing good, thank you for asking.

14
00:00:36.080 --> 00:00:39.940
So Jo,
we left off talking about our SMS, but

15
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:42.570
where did we leave off and
where will we begin for this show?

16
00:00:42.570 --> 00:00:46.996
>> Yeah, so yesterday we started off with
looking at service management system and

17
00:00:46.996 --> 00:00:51.303
we looked at obviously the concept of
the logical service management system.

18
00:00:51.303 --> 00:00:55.520
And the fact that it is not
actually an IT system, per se, and

19
00:00:55.520 --> 00:00:57.670
it is not about the tools.

20
00:00:57.670 --> 00:01:01.390
It is actually about the way that we
manage and the way that we go in and

21
00:01:01.390 --> 00:01:05.540
the policies that we define and
the processes that we define for

22
00:01:05.540 --> 00:01:07.160
our IT service providers.

23
00:01:07.160 --> 00:01:11.670
So yesterday we looked
at establishing an SMS,

24
00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:13.780
establishing a service management system.

25
00:01:13.780 --> 00:01:18.630
And in fact,
we finished off looking at the slide

26
00:01:18.630 --> 00:01:23.650
that's just appeared right now as if
by magic, where we look at the Plan,

27
00:01:23.650 --> 00:01:28.570
Do, Check, Act element of
the service management system.

28
00:01:28.570 --> 00:01:31.110
In other words,
implementing a service management system,

29
00:01:31.110 --> 00:01:35.410
implementing a protocol for
governance and a protocol for

30
00:01:35.410 --> 00:01:41.360
the way that we manage our services,
and our people, and our processes.

31
00:01:41.360 --> 00:01:44.170
Well, it's not just a one off action.

32
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:48.400
It's not something we can do and
then we can just forget about it.

33
00:01:48.400 --> 00:01:51.310
We have to ensure that we
are subject to continual

34
00:01:51.310 --> 00:01:54.280
improvement because
the organization changes.

35
00:01:54.280 --> 00:01:58.290
And so, on the right hand side there you
have what we might also call the Deming

36
00:01:58.290 --> 00:02:04.310
cycle, which is that iterative cycle for
improvement where we plan for

37
00:02:04.310 --> 00:02:07.140
improvements, we plan for
changes, we do them.

38
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:08.944
We've checked that they've worked.

39
00:02:08.944 --> 00:02:16.670
And then we, from checking that they've
worked, we can then take mediate action.

40
00:02:16.670 --> 00:02:21.610
We can then recommend further
opportunities and ideas for improvement.

41
00:02:21.610 --> 00:02:22.830
And that's part of the Act.

42
00:02:22.830 --> 00:02:25.860
The Act is looking for
new ways to improve.

43
00:02:27.120 --> 00:02:32.670
So we have to bear in mind that when we
define our service management system and

44
00:02:32.670 --> 00:02:36.410
our way of governing and
our way of managing our IT services and

45
00:02:36.410 --> 00:02:38.640
their processes and the people as well,

46
00:02:38.640 --> 00:02:42.895
then we have to bear in mind that
this has to be an iterative process.

47
00:02:42.895 --> 00:02:45.985
This is not something that's
just a one-off experience.

48
00:02:45.985 --> 00:02:48.905
So this is what we finished
off with yesterday.

49
00:02:48.905 --> 00:02:52.987
Just looking at the iterative
implementation of our

50
00:02:52.987 --> 00:02:57.067
service management system and
our way of managing.

51
00:02:57.067 --> 00:03:00.157
And I know that it's really really easy,
you hear the word system and

52
00:03:00.157 --> 00:03:02.087
you automatically think, tools.

53
00:03:02.087 --> 00:03:06.777
And of course, I'm gonna start off again
in this particular episode with that

54
00:03:06.777 --> 00:03:09.487
warning that it's not
just about the tools,

55
00:03:09.487 --> 00:03:13.797
it's about the way of
managing our IT services.

56
00:03:13.797 --> 00:03:18.477
And of course, what we are auditing
in our ISO 20000 audit,

57
00:03:18.477 --> 00:03:24.108
which ISO 20000 sounds a lot
easier than ISO/IEC 20000 2011.

58
00:03:24.108 --> 00:03:25.204
>> It's true enough, Jo.

59
00:03:25.204 --> 00:03:28.220
>> [LAUGH] So
we'll stick with that one going forward.

60
00:03:28.220 --> 00:03:29.650
But in our ISO 20000 auditing,

61
00:03:29.650 --> 00:03:34.680
what we are auditing is not that
you have a tool in place, but

62
00:03:34.680 --> 00:03:40.370
we're auditing that you have an entire
system in place for managing IT and

63
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:44.460
that you have all of the policies and
the processes and they're all documented.

64
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:50.140
And of course,
don't forget my constant nagging voice

65
00:03:50.140 --> 00:03:55.080
that will appear in your head every time
you approach an audit which is show me,

66
00:03:55.080 --> 00:03:56.970
I want you to show me the evidence.

67
00:03:58.060 --> 00:04:01.150
So what about our service
management system then?

68
00:04:01.150 --> 00:04:05.290
Well, what should our service
management system produce?

69
00:04:05.290 --> 00:04:08.430
Well, what it should produce in
the outputs are our process plans,

70
00:04:08.430 --> 00:04:11.700
and our plans for managing our services,
and our plans for

71
00:04:11.700 --> 00:04:13.700
measuring those services as well.

72
00:04:15.090 --> 00:04:19.486
The service management
system has to be planned.

73
00:04:19.486 --> 00:04:24.000
I don't know that this sounds like
we're using just that word planning way

74
00:04:24.000 --> 00:04:26.330
too much but
I want to see evidence of that.

75
00:04:26.330 --> 00:04:33.815
If we are auditing you for ISO 20000, then
what that means is that we are auditing to

76
00:04:33.815 --> 00:04:38.925
ensure that your service management system
was planned, that it didn't just happen.

77
00:04:38.925 --> 00:04:43.135
That you haven't just got a set
of desperate processes and

78
00:04:43.135 --> 00:04:47.120
a set of desperate services and you really
don't know how anything is managed.

79
00:04:47.120 --> 00:04:52.520
I want to see that you have got a plan for
managing your services,

80
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:55.720
so that you've got a policy here in
your input center into this plan.

81
00:04:55.720 --> 00:04:59.810
You've got a policy, you understand your
service requirements, and, of course,

82
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:04.030
you understand the ISO 20000
Part 1 requirements as well.

83
00:05:04.030 --> 00:05:08.900
Those mandatory requirements that
you will need to demonstrate

84
00:05:08.900 --> 00:05:11.100
to an auditor that you are achieving.

85
00:05:12.520 --> 00:05:17.087
And so, you'll create a plan for
your service management system.

86
00:05:17.087 --> 00:05:20.152
So as it says in the bullet points
at the bottom, there's plans for

87
00:05:20.152 --> 00:05:21.750
your specific processes.

88
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:26.570
Well, they form part of the overall
service management plan.

89
00:05:27.580 --> 00:05:32.100
Then, of course, like any single
document and every single process and

90
00:05:32.100 --> 00:05:37.650
every single service,
they are subject to continual review.

91
00:05:37.650 --> 00:05:40.220
That's why we want to have
continual improvement.

92
00:05:40.220 --> 00:05:43.990
We want to make sure, so as I have already
said, that this is not a one of activity,

93
00:05:43.990 --> 00:05:47.620
it is something that we
are doing on a regular basis.

94
00:05:47.620 --> 00:05:50.555
Just a quick question though Cherokee,

95
00:05:50.555 --> 00:05:56.182
how often do you think that I want to see
evidence of you reviewing your plans?

96
00:05:56.182 --> 00:05:58.669
>> All right,
[LAUGH] at least quarterly and

97
00:05:58.669 --> 00:06:04.150
anytime we're implementing a significant
change within our environment.

98
00:06:04.150 --> 00:06:07.620
>> It depends on the scale of
the organization, to be honest.

99
00:06:07.620 --> 00:06:09.850
I would say at least once a year.

100
00:06:09.850 --> 00:06:11.780
Plans should be updated
at least once a year, but

101
00:06:11.780 --> 00:06:14.380
it does depend on the scale
of the organization.

102
00:06:14.380 --> 00:06:18.835
And an organization that
is subject to rapid growth,

103
00:06:18.835 --> 00:06:22.180
then yes, we'd be looking for a more-
>> A shorter interval.

104
00:06:22.180 --> 00:06:23.169
>> More aggressive.

105
00:06:23.169 --> 00:06:23.770
>> Okay, more aggressive.
>> Yeah,

106
00:06:23.770 --> 00:06:26.120
a more aggressive schedule for this.

107
00:06:26.120 --> 00:06:29.410
But don't forget though,
when you're reviewing plans,

108
00:06:29.410 --> 00:06:31.960
that in itself is going to take time.

109
00:06:31.960 --> 00:06:35.660
And so, if you are subject to rapid
growth or if you're in a very very small

110
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:41.010
organization, then you don't always have
the time to review absolutely everything.

111
00:06:41.010 --> 00:06:44.330
And maybe after three months you haven't
quite got everything implemented, and

112
00:06:44.330 --> 00:06:45.830
then you're reviewing it again already.

113
00:06:45.830 --> 00:06:47.370
>> Yeah, that makes sense.

114
00:06:47.370 --> 00:06:53.510
>> Yeah, so think sensibly and there is no
set time frame for reviewing these plans.

115
00:06:53.510 --> 00:06:57.670
You're right about after any major change,
most definitely after any major change and

116
00:06:57.670 --> 00:07:00.420
also after any major disaster as well.

117
00:07:00.420 --> 00:07:04.180
So if we've had to invoke some
form of service continuity or

118
00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:07.690
disaster recovery I expect to see
plans reviewed at that point in time.

119
00:07:07.690 --> 00:07:09.630
You know the lessons learned?

120
00:07:09.630 --> 00:07:14.325
But yeah, after any major change,
but certainly at least once a year,

121
00:07:14.325 --> 00:07:17.290
I'd expect to see that, as a bare minimum.

122
00:07:17.290 --> 00:07:21.150
Sure it could be more frequent, but bare
in mind you don't wanna be too disruptive.

123
00:07:21.150 --> 00:07:23.381
>> So
that you can continue to be productive and

124
00:07:23.381 --> 00:07:26.350
not worrying about reviewing or
doing the back end stuff.

125
00:07:26.350 --> 00:07:31.226
>> Right and in terms of worrying about
doing these things, these things should be

126
00:07:31.226 --> 00:07:36.740
fairly, well, I'm gonna see evidence of
that fact that they're very well-managed.

127
00:07:36.740 --> 00:07:37.668
And so therefore,

128
00:07:37.668 --> 00:07:41.034
it should be something that should
happen on a regular basis anyway.

129
00:07:41.034 --> 00:07:45.716
That if we've got the working
document repository system,

130
00:07:45.716 --> 00:07:50.668
if we have got the right plans in
place and the right SMS in place,

131
00:07:50.668 --> 00:07:55.716
then that SMS is going to facilitate
us reviewing the plans anyway

132
00:07:55.716 --> 00:08:00.345
cuz it's going to be Embedded
into the actual plan itself.

133
00:08:00.345 --> 00:08:04.906
It's gonna embedded into the service
management system that we

134
00:08:04.906 --> 00:08:09.140
are going to review all of our plans and
all of our policies.

135
00:08:09.140 --> 00:08:11.540
So we should be doing
this on a regular basis.

136
00:08:11.540 --> 00:08:14.730
And all process owners
should be accountable for

137
00:08:14.730 --> 00:08:17.160
reviewing our processes
on a regular basis.

138
00:08:17.160 --> 00:08:20.780
And yes, in an order I wanna see
evidence that they've been reviewed.

139
00:08:20.780 --> 00:08:23.850
I wanna see evidence that they've been
reviewed in the past and I also would

140
00:08:23.850 --> 00:08:29.260
wanna see evidence that they are scheduled
for review in the future as well.

141
00:08:29.260 --> 00:08:31.040
All of this evidence has to be produced,
and

142
00:08:31.040 --> 00:08:36.260
that's something that we have to bear
in mind when it comes to ISO 20000.

143
00:08:36.260 --> 00:08:40.660
In an audit,
we've got to see the evidence of this.

144
00:08:40.660 --> 00:08:43.320
So it's not just enough to say,
yeah we looked at that last week.

145
00:08:44.670 --> 00:08:47.630
I wanna see some sort of documentary
evidence on how we do that.

146
00:08:47.630 --> 00:08:52.790
I mean when you think about this,
how do I know that you've read a document?

147
00:08:54.880 --> 00:09:02.890
>> Maybe it's some kind of quiz at the end
to verify my absorption of the knowledge?

148
00:09:04.120 --> 00:09:06.380
>> Kinda seems like a lot of effort.

149
00:09:06.380 --> 00:09:07.400
>> Yeah.

150
00:09:07.400 --> 00:09:09.130
>> Cuz somebody's got to compile a quiz.

151
00:09:09.130 --> 00:09:10.189
>> Yeah.
So that.

152
00:09:10.189 --> 00:09:12.670
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Unless you trust me Joe.

153
00:09:12.670 --> 00:09:15.150
>> Right, so how do I know then.

154
00:09:15.150 --> 00:09:17.680
Let's say it was a service-level
agreement document.

155
00:09:17.680 --> 00:09:20.090
We all know about
service-level agreements?

156
00:09:20.090 --> 00:09:20.660
>> Right.

157
00:09:20.660 --> 00:09:22.850
>> So let's say I wanted to check.

158
00:09:22.850 --> 00:09:27.660
I ask you to show me evidence that
service-level agreement document has

159
00:09:27.660 --> 00:09:30.670
been reviewed at least every year.

160
00:09:30.670 --> 00:09:32.110
How are you gonna do that?

161
00:09:32.110 --> 00:09:36.950
>> I could provide reports if it
were something that I was, like,

162
00:09:36.950 --> 00:09:37.970
monitoring actively.

163
00:09:37.970 --> 00:09:38.470
>> Right.

164
00:09:39.650 --> 00:09:44.240
So you'd provide reports on what,
the fact that I opened the document, or

165

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee introduce Service Delivery. Jo explains how service delivery focuses on delivering the agreed services to the agreed service targets. She outlines the "shalls" and provides examples of what would be expected during an audit. A catalogue of services, documentation for a service, SLA components and service reporting index examples are explained.
