00:27:26.330 --> 00:27:28.950
You've got to demonstrate that
that's exactly what's happening.

480
00:27:30.240 --> 00:27:33.440
So we have to, again, this is a shall.

481
00:27:33.440 --> 00:27:38.600
A shall is we have to monitor,
we have to report costs against budget,

482
00:27:38.600 --> 00:27:42.640
we have to perform adequate accounting,

483
00:27:42.640 --> 00:27:45.430
that's accounting for
how much money have I spent.

484
00:27:45.430 --> 00:27:51.070
We have to demonstrate that we can manage
costs, and we have to demonstrate that we

485
00:27:51.070 --> 00:27:57.180
can, well,
that we have a bottom line in effect.

486
00:27:57.180 --> 00:28:00.240
We can demonstrate we're
providing value for money, and

487
00:28:00.240 --> 00:28:02.590
that IT is not a cost center.

488
00:28:02.590 --> 00:28:05.110
It doesn't necessarily have
to be a profit center.

489
00:28:05.110 --> 00:28:10.030
But it's not just a drain on resources,
which is how some organizations view IT.

490
00:28:10.030 --> 00:28:13.380
I mean, let's take a look at
the boxes down the bottom.

491
00:28:13.380 --> 00:28:17.060
Think about shared resources,
think about our overheads,

492
00:28:17.060 --> 00:28:20.860
think about the facilities and
our personnel, these are all costs.

493
00:28:21.940 --> 00:28:25.700
Now how do you demonstrate that somebody
is actually an asset to an organization?

494
00:28:25.700 --> 00:28:27.550
You have to be able to do that.

495
00:28:27.550 --> 00:28:28.260
>> Right.

496
00:28:28.260 --> 00:28:31.550
And especially for the IT department,
things like taking advantage and

497
00:28:31.550 --> 00:28:33.010
leveraging ticketing systems.

498
00:28:33.010 --> 00:28:34.870
Well I think what did you say before,
we don't-

499
00:28:34.870 --> 00:28:36.050
>> We don't call them that.

500
00:28:36.050 --> 00:28:36.650
>> Yeah, okay!

501
00:28:36.650 --> 00:28:38.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's just my terminology.

502
00:28:38.330 --> 00:28:42.230
But some way to document, look,
Cherokee spent x amount of hours

503
00:28:42.230 --> 00:28:47.230
handling this particular incident,
or I was troubleshooting for

504
00:28:47.230 --> 00:28:49.790
x amount of hours and
then fill it out accordingly that way.

505
00:28:49.790 --> 00:28:50.916
>> A lot of organizations, and

506
00:28:50.916 --> 00:28:54.280
a lot of people don't like to
actually fill out time sheets.

507
00:28:54.280 --> 00:28:56.110
And we all hate to fill out time sheets.

508
00:28:56.110 --> 00:29:00.520
However, in order to achieve ISO 20000,
we've got to

509
00:29:00.520 --> 00:29:05.070
have articulated demonstrable proof
that we're delivering value for money.

510
00:29:05.070 --> 00:29:08.620
So, you know, I have to be able to
demonstrate that I am not paying you to

511
00:29:08.620 --> 00:29:10.330
sit around and twiddle your thumbs-
>> Right.

512
00:29:10.330 --> 00:29:11.530
>> And drink coffee all day.

513
00:29:11.530 --> 00:29:14.660
You know, I have to demonstrate that
I am actually getting value for

514
00:29:14.660 --> 00:29:18.585
money out of you, and that means value for
money out of your skills and value for

515
00:29:18.585 --> 00:29:24.355
money out of your time, and what you
can contribute to the organization.

516
00:29:24.355 --> 00:29:29.833
So that means then that whilst we don't
like to do any form of time management,

517
00:29:29.833 --> 00:29:33.402
and we don't like to do any
form of logging down what

518
00:29:33.402 --> 00:29:36.845
we've done for the day-
>> Well, just remember it may even keep

519
00:29:36.845 --> 00:29:40.245
you employed if you look at, you know,
a comparison between employees.

520
00:29:40.245 --> 00:29:45.730
And one employee is significantly
lacking as far as completed tickets or

521
00:29:45.730 --> 00:29:47.284
whatever terminology you use.

522
00:29:47.284 --> 00:29:49.646
>> [LAUGH] Not tickets, Right?

523
00:29:49.646 --> 00:29:50.700
Not tickets.

524
00:29:50.700 --> 00:29:55.015
>> [LAUGH] Service incidents,
okay, but I don't know.

525
00:29:55.015 --> 00:29:58.560
>> [LAUGH] [LAUGH]
>> Let's go to that point in time.

526
00:29:58.560 --> 00:30:01.780
This is the time where we say no,
let's go now [LAUGH].

527
00:30:01.780 --> 00:30:04.730
>> Okay, but anyways, yeah,
it's definitely useful.

528
00:30:04.730 --> 00:30:05.944
I can see the value in that.

529
00:30:05.944 --> 00:30:07.200
>> Yeah, we have to do that.

530
00:30:07.200 --> 00:30:09.465
I mean we wouldn't necessarily
advocate comparing-

531
00:30:09.465 --> 00:30:10.177
>> [LAUGH]

532
00:30:10.177 --> 00:30:11.485
>> People with each other.

533
00:30:11.485 --> 00:30:14.700
[LAUGH] But nevertheless, we have to
demonstrate that we're getting value for

534
00:30:14.700 --> 00:30:16.966
money from our people-
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

535
00:30:16.966 --> 00:30:18.299
>> As well as from all
of our resources too.

536
00:30:18.299 --> 00:30:22.600
So yes, I mean, we have to be able
to identify training needs, etc.

537
00:30:22.600 --> 00:30:25.920
And it's all about getting value for
money out of people.

538
00:30:25.920 --> 00:30:29.460
But as I've jokingly just said,
let's leave it there for a moment.

539
00:30:29.460 --> 00:30:35.790
And I think what we'll do is we will say
that's it for this particular episode.

540
00:30:35.790 --> 00:30:40.280
We will come back in our next episode and
we will carry on with clause six and

541
00:30:40.280 --> 00:30:45.200
we will carry on taking a look at
the remaining service delivery

542
00:30:45.200 --> 00:30:46.650
processes here in clause six-
>> Okay, so

543
00:30:46.650 --> 00:30:49.260
we've made it to part
three here in clause six.

544
00:30:49.260 --> 00:30:50.250
>> We have yes.

545
00:30:50.250 --> 00:30:51.970
>> So ladies and
gentlemen stay tuned for that.

546
00:30:51.970 --> 00:30:54.240
But for this show we'll go ahead and
sign out now.

547
00:30:54.240 --> 00:30:55.760
I've been your host Cherokee Booths.

548
00:30:55.760 --> 00:30:56.720
>> And I'm Joe Pecocks.

549
00:30:56.720 --> 00:31:03.522
>> See you next time here on ITPro TV.

550
00:31:03.522 --> 00:31:05.320
>> [MUSIC].

551
00:31:05.320 --> 00:31:07.989
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee explain the scope of the capacity management process. Jo states it  includes the planning and management of capacity for human, technical information and financial resources. She shares an example of capacity requirements  to help ensure that capacity requirements can be agreed, forecast and met.
episodes.title: Clause 6 - Service Delivery Processes Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:02.614
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.614 --> 00:00:07.330
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.330 --> 00:00:10.448
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.448 --> 00:00:17.363
>> Welcome back to your ISO/IEC
20000:2011 Foundation series.

5
00:00:17.363 --> 00:00:20.400
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:20.400 --> 00:00:24.960
And this episode we'll pick back up
here at clause six with a part three.

7
00:00:24.960 --> 00:00:28.730
Specifically we'll be looking
at service delivery processes.

8
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:32.300
And back in studios with us today
we have ISO expert, Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:32.300 --> 00:00:33.540
How you doing, Jo?

10
00:00:33.540 --> 00:00:34.960
>> I'm doing great, thank you, Cherokee.

11
00:00:34.960 --> 00:00:35.870
How are you?

12
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:38.130
>> I'm well,
I'm ready to pick back up here so

13
00:00:38.130 --> 00:00:42.000
we can kinda round things
out looking at clause six.

14
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:44.850
So, what is the first topic
that we'll be discussing here?

15
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:47.360
>> Well, we're still in our
service delivery processes.

16
00:00:47.360 --> 00:00:51.130
So in our delivery processes,
we've been looking at availability and

17
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:52.260
continuity management.

18
00:00:52.260 --> 00:00:55.580
We've been looking at reporting and
service-level management.

19
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:58.910
And so, now what we're going to do is
take a look at capacity management.

20
00:00:58.910 --> 00:01:04.730
So we're gonna jump right in Looking at
the requirements for capacity management.

21
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:08.740
Now, one of the first things that I wanna
tell you about capacity management is

22
00:01:08.740 --> 00:01:16.360
that, capacity relates to the capacity for
all our components within IT.

23
00:01:16.360 --> 00:01:20.610
So it's making sure that we have
the right amount of capacity to meet

24
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.360
all of the requirements
of the organization.

25
00:01:24.710 --> 00:01:27.500
What I actually mean by that
is that we've got enough

26
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:29.670
capacity in terms of
the technical capacity,

27
00:01:29.670 --> 00:01:32.920
in other words we've got enough bandwidth,
we've got enough memory.

28
00:01:32.920 --> 00:01:36.056
We've also got enough capacity
in terms of information.

29
00:01:36.056 --> 00:01:41.206
And I don't mean just by having enough
capacity to store our documents, but

30
00:01:41.206 --> 00:01:46.840
also having enough capacity in terms
of training information, for instance.

31
00:01:46.840 --> 00:01:50.310
So enough capacity in terms of information

32
00:01:50.310 --> 00:01:53.450
to be able to meet the needs
of the organization.

33
00:01:53.450 --> 00:01:56.430
So we have to have enough information.

34
00:01:56.430 --> 00:02:00.190
It's not just about being able
to store it somewhere, but

35
00:02:00.190 --> 00:02:02.260
it's actually having
it in the first place.

36
00:02:02.260 --> 00:02:04.950
>> Access to those resources for
our employees.

37
00:02:04.950 --> 00:02:06.750
>> Well not just access to the resources.

38
00:02:06.750 --> 00:02:08.388
We have to have the resources.

39
00:02:08.388 --> 00:02:09.270
>> [LAUGH] True.

40
00:02:09.270 --> 00:02:13.800
>> [LAUGH] And we can't just simply
turn around and say, hey, there you go,

41
00:02:13.800 --> 00:02:14.970
log on and use an email.

42
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:19.440
We've gotta tell somebody how to log
on and use an email or send an email.

43
00:02:19.440 --> 00:02:22.640
And then we've gotta have enough
capacity in terms of money.

44
00:02:22.640 --> 00:02:24.430
We've gotta have enough money.

45
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:29.020
And we're not just talking about things
like being able to pay our bills,

46
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:30.640
being able to pay our licenses.

47
00:02:30.640 --> 00:02:34.410
But also, we have to have enough money
to be able to pay our people as well.

48
00:02:35.580 --> 00:02:41.900
And that comes onto the, and you notice
I've left into last, the human capacity.

49
00:02:41.900 --> 00:02:45.330
And when we talk about human capacity,
I mean having enough people with

50
00:02:45.330 --> 00:02:49.820
the right amount of skills to be able to
meet the needs of the organization and

51
00:02:49.820 --> 00:02:52.690
meet the needs of our business itself.

52
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:55.130
>> And
even those last two may go together Jo,

53
00:02:55.130 --> 00:02:58.480
because if we think about this industry,
the nature of it.

54
00:02:58.480 --> 00:03:01.610
And it's constantly evolving,
then a lot of those companies,

55
00:03:01.610 --> 00:03:03.980
they should be providing
continual education so

56
00:03:03.980 --> 00:03:08.090
that their employees can be
relevant in today's technologies.

57
00:03:08.090 --> 00:03:11.207
>> Well, this actually is what
capacity management covers.

58
00:03:11.207 --> 00:03:12.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, yeah,

59
00:03:12.660 --> 00:03:14.180
I'm really glad that
you've mentioned that.

60
00:03:14.180 --> 00:03:16.480
Cuz we talk about continual improvement.

61
00:03:16.480 --> 00:03:20.746
And we talk about continual improvement,
when we looked at our ITIL framework,

62
00:03:20.746 --> 00:03:23.710
we looked at continual improvement for
our processes.

63
00:03:23.710 --> 00:03:26.335
But here within ISO 20000,

64
00:03:26.335 --> 00:03:32.600
we're measuring our ability to be able
to deliver value to our customers.

65
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:36.460
And here we're measuring not only that
we have the right number of people,

66
00:03:36.460 --> 00:03:38.220
but they have the right skills.

67
00:03:38.220 --> 00:03:43.100
And of course every time we bring in a new
service, then we're probably going to have

68
00:03:43.100 --> 00:03:48.390
to revisit how many support people we have
and the skills of those support people.

69
00:03:48.390 --> 00:03:53.040
And as we move into a strategy
supporting the strategy for

70
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:57.410
the organization, whatever that strategy
may be that the organization has and

71
00:03:57.410 --> 00:04:02.050
we've got to make sure that we in
IT are able to support any strategy

72
00:04:02.050 --> 00:04:05.410
that the organization
may want to implement.

73
00:04:05.410 --> 00:04:11.390
So, when it says here under part 2,
this is the intent, this is a should.

74
00:04:11.390 --> 00:04:16.210
We should be in a position
where we as a service provider

75
00:04:16.210 --> 00:04:20.830
have enough capacity to meet the current
and future needs of the organization.

76
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:23.210
And that is not just in
relation to technical,

77
00:04:23.210 --> 00:04:26.420
which is the first place
that we go to in IT.

78
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:30.565
So what are we actually auditing against?

79
00:04:30.565 --> 00:04:33.320
Well, I want to see, remember the show me?

80
00:04:33.320 --> 00:04:38.090
I want to see that you have got
documented capacity requirements.

81
00:04:39.280 --> 00:04:42.980
And that you have enough capacity
to meet the requirements.

82
00:04:42.980 --> 00:04:47.440
So, that you have a plan in place for how
you are going to meet those requirements

83
00:04:47.440 --> 00:04:52.040
and that you are able to
monitor your capacity usage and

84
00:04:52.040 --> 00:04:56.220
that you're able to predict
capacity usage as well.

85
00:04:56.220 --> 00:04:58.070
That's what the plan is all about.

86
00:04:58.070 --> 00:05:02.930
And that's why we're able to, we need
to be able to analyze capacity usage.

87
00:05:02.930 --> 00:05:08.720
And when able to perform fine
tuning activities as well,

88
00:05:08.720 --> 00:05:11.150
and I wanna see evidence of all those.

89
00:05:11.150 --> 00:05:14.360
So I want to see that capacity
is routinely managed.

90
00:05:14.360 --> 00:05:15.100
I want to see.

91
00:05:15.100 --> 00:05:16.700
I don't want to just
turn around to you and

92
00:05:16.700 --> 00:05:21.290
say what's the bandwidth utilization
currently on your network?

93
00:05:21.290 --> 00:05:25.760
I want to see what the bandwidth
utilization is on your network or

94
00:05:25.760 --> 00:05:28.860
what it has been over the past month and
over the past six months.

95
00:05:28.860 --> 00:05:30.140
And what's the trend?

96
00:05:30.140 --> 00:05:31.910
Show me your peaks and your troughs.

97
00:05:31.910 --> 00:05:35.650
When is bandwidth excessively utilized,
when is it not?

98
00:05:36.820 --> 00:05:42.026
Now, we have processes that covered
within the ITIL framework that

99
00:05:42.026 --> 00:05:48.347
would help you to manage your capacity and
help you to identify peaks and troughs.

100
00:05:48.347 --> 00:05:53.320
So they will help you to
achieve your ISO 20000.

101
00:05:53.320 --> 00:05:58.398
So if you're looking for techniques
to help you demonstrate the part 1,

102
00:05:58.398 --> 00:06:03.160
the shalls, then ITIL is not a bad
place to start because they have some

103
00:06:03.160 --> 00:06:06.190
processes in place that
can help you with this.

104
00:06:06.190 --> 00:06:10.770
Ultimately, we are concerned with
the capacity of all of our components.

105
00:06:10.770 --> 00:06:15.100
And the components of our service
includes software and hardware.

106
00:06:15.100 --> 00:06:18.020
But it also includes
the environmental components.

107
00:06:18.020 --> 00:06:23.050
Have we got enough outlets in our
walls to be able to plug in and

108
00:06:23.050 --> 00:06:26.750
I mean electrical outlets,
to be able to plug in all of our devices?

109
00:06:26.750 --> 00:06:30.650
Have we got enough network ports in our
walls to be able to plug in in our devices

110
00:06:30.650 --> 00:06:31.570
for instance?

111
00:06:31.570 --> 00:06:35.070
So we're talking about having enough
capacity for all of our components.

112
00:06:35.070 --> 00:06:37.790
And having enough capacity for
our services and

113
00:06:37.790 --> 00:06:42.550
having enough capacity to meet
the entire needs of the organization.

114
00:06:43.630 --> 00:06:45.540
We have to have a capacity plan.

115
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:51.070
And that plan has to include, now these
are the shalls, this is your part 1.

116
00:06:51.070 --> 00:06:54.340
So I'm gonna say to you,
show me the evidence.

117
00:06:54.340 --> 00:06:59.080
Your plan has to include the human and
the technical and

118
00:06:59.080 --> 00:07:03.560
the data and
financial planning for capacity.

119
00:07:03.560 --> 00:07:06.590
It includes, as I've already said,
and this is what I want to see,

120
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:07.980
this is your shall.

121
00:07:07.980 --> 00:07:10.860
I want to see your current
capacity utilization.

122
00:07:10.860 --> 00:07:14.009
And I want to see
a forecast based on trends.

123
00:07:15.060 --> 00:07:16.960
I want to see expected impact.

124
00:07:16.960 --> 00:07:19.530
I want to see a risk analysis.

125
00:07:19.530 --> 00:07:23.840
I want to see timescales, I want to
see thresholds, I want to see custom

126
00:07:23.840 --> 00:07:28.640
information, I want to see impactive
changes on capacity utilization.

127
00:07:29.650 --> 00:07:32.650
And I want to see, as I've already said,
I wanna see trending and

128
00:07:32.650 --> 00:07:35.190
therefore I want to see predictions.

129
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:40.400
I want to see my plans for
capacity utilization.

130
00:07:40.400 --> 00:07:43.620
This, after all, is,
at the moment, the plan.

131
00:07:43.620 --> 00:07:47.310
And so, therefore, in my plan,
we've got to do some planning.

132
00:07:47.310 --> 00:07:49.030
It's not all about looking backwards.

133
00:07:49.030 --> 00:07:51.820
It's not all about seeing
what we've done in the past.

134
00:07:51.820 --> 00:07:55.520
It's about seeing what we're
going to do in the future and

135
00:07:55.520 --> 00:07:57.480
what we need in the future.

136
00:07:59.510 --> 00:08:02.490
So, that's capacity management.

137
00:08:02.490 --> 00:08:07.396
And capacity management, as you can see,
out of the 259 requirements

138
00:08:07.396 --> 00:08:11.810
that there are within part 1,
our mandatory requirements.

139
00:08:11.810 --> 00:08:12.980
And capacity management,

140
00:08:12.980 --> 00:08:16.260
you might think well it doesn't
really have too many requirements.

141
00:08:17.460 --> 00:08:19.690
But it does, just think about
how in depth they need to be.

142
00:08:19.690 --> 00:08:21.320
>> Well I was kind of curious about that.

143
00:08:21.320 --> 00:08:23.430
I see how you have your
bullet points there, Jo.

144
00:08:23.430 --> 00:08:27.970
But then you have those sub,
the indentions for those dependencies.

145
00:08:27.970 --> 00:08:30.722
So would those be counted
as part of that 259?

146
00:08:30.722 --> 00:08:31.222
>> Yes.
>> Okay.

147
00:08:31.222 --> 00:08:34.120
>> Yes, it has to include this.

148
00:08:34.120 --> 00:08:37.130
So they would be,
when I say would they be part of the 259,

149
00:08:37.130 --> 00:08:40.210
the scope is part of the 259.

150
00:08:40.210 --> 00:08:44.760
>> Okay, so those are not technically
accounted for with that numerical value.

151
00:08:44.760 --> 00:08:47.211
Those are just required as well.

152
00:08:47.211 --> 00:08:48.871
>> Right,
well they're not required as well,

153
00:08:48.871 --> 00:08:51.245
that's what I expect to see in the scope.

154
00:08:51.245 --> 00:08:56.595
So I expect to see a plan and
I expect the plan to include human,

155
00:08:56.595 --> 00:08:58.955
technical, information and
financial resources.

156
00:08:58.955 --> 00:09:03.940
So if I see a plan that doesn't have
any mention for human resources, for

157
00:09:03.940 --> 00:09:08.362
instance, then I'm gonna say, no,
I'm sorry, but that's not adequate.

158
00:09:08.362 --> 00:09:10.230
>> Okay.

159
00:09:10.230 --> 00:09:14.750
It depends on the scale, but
that would be either a major or

160
00:09:14.750 --> 00:09:17.270
minor non-conformance, but
it would be a nonconformance.

161
00:09:17.270 --> 00:09:21.110
Because even though the scope
itself is just one requirement,

162
00:09:21.110 --> 00:09:25.270
it doesn't meet all of
the specifications for that requirement.

163
00:09:25.270 --> 00:09:27.410
>> Okay, so
we wouldn't be checking off one, two,

164
00:09:27.410 --> 00:09:30.660
three, four,
five off of our checklist there.

165
00:09:30.660 --> 00:09:31.760
We'd just be checking the one.

166
00:09:31.760 --> 00:09:32.430
>> Just the one, yeah.

167
00:09:34.050 --> 00:09:35.854
And we've got 259 of these.

168
00:09:35.854 --> 00:09:37.513
>> Okay.

169
00:09:37.513 --> 00:09:39.859
>> So just a few, that's okay, just a few.

170
00:09:40.970 --> 00:09:44.250
So let's take a look then at
security management then.

171
00:09:44.250 --> 00:09:48.698
Now, we do acknowledge
security management and

172
00:09:48.698 --> 00:09:52.612
you'll see that we've got a part 2 here.

173
00:09:52.612 --> 00:09:57.580
And part 2 is just that you should
have security controls in place, okay?

174
00:09:57.580 --> 00:10:01.730
This is your part 2,
we should be protecting our, think CIA,

175
00:10:01.730 --> 00:10:06.610
our confidentiality, integrity and
availability of our information.

176
00:10:06.610 --> 00:10:10.195
Making sure that it's kept confidential,
that we can ensure the integrity,

177
00:10:10.195 --> 00:10:13.365
and that it's only available to
those that should have access to it.

178
00:10:13.365 --> 00:10:17.798
But we have ISO 27002, that is the latest

179
00:10:17.798 --> 00:10:23.610
version of the International Standard
of Security.

180
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:29.232
So whilst we will cover security
to a certain level within

181
00:10:29.232 --> 00:10:34.268
ISO 20000,
we do not cover it in depth because

182
00:10:34.268 --> 00:10:39.202
there is a separate standard for
ISO 27002.

183
00:10:39.202 --> 00:10:44.060
With that said, there are a lot of
organizations that don't want to accredit

184
00:10:44.060 --> 00:10:48.694
themselves with an ISO 27002, but
they still want to achieve the ISO

185
00:10:48.694 --> 00:10:53.950
20000 accreditation, which means that
we've gotta think about security.

186
00:10:53.950 --> 00:10:58.842
You can't just ignore security and
pretend it's not happening because if

187
00:10:58.842 --> 00:11:02.723
you don't have the right
security restrictions in place,

188
00:11:02.723 --> 00:11:07.710
then quite simply, you won't actually
be able to achieve ISO 20000.

189
00:11:07.710 --> 00:11:11.760
Or at least you won't be able to retain it
for very long, because things will change.

190
00:11:11.760 --> 00:11:19.610
[LAUGH] Because your security is too,
well I was gonna use the word scarce.

191
00:11:19.610 --> 00:11:23.340
It's not necessarily scarce but
if it's not robust enough then obviously--

192
00:11:23.340 --> 00:11:24.400
>> And adequate.

193
00:11:24.400 --> 00:11:26.500
>> Yeah and adequate works.

194
00:11:26.500 --> 00:11:28.870
We wanna make sure that you
do have security in place.

195
00:11:30.300 --> 00:11:33.550
So your security policy itself.

196
00:11:35.000 --> 00:11:36.760
Here is a shall.

197
00:11:36.760 --> 00:11:39.630
The security policy is
approved by management.

198
00:11:39.630 --> 00:11:44.615
So, the policy that is
available to everybody, well,

199
00:11:44.615 --> 00:11:47.030
it needs to be approved by management.

200
00:11:47.030 --> 00:11:51.460
Management should communicate
the policy to appropriate people.

201
00:11:51.460 --> 00:11:52.480
Just as a quick question.

202
00:11:52.480 --> 00:11:55.570
Who do you think should have
access to your security policy?

203
00:11:55.570 --> 00:11:57.440
>> Everyone in the organization.

204
00:11:57.440 --> 00:12:00.495
>> Right, yeah, absolutely everybody.

205
00:12:00.495 --> 00:12:05.270
And it says here that management have
a responsibility and this is a shall.

206
00:12:05.270 --> 00:12:08.950
Management have a responsibility
to communicate the policy to

207
00:12:08.950 --> 00:12:10.290
appropriate personal.

208
00:12:10.290 --> 00:12:13.620
So do you one of the things
that I do to check this?

209
00:12:13.620 --> 00:12:15.940
>> You go around and
ask a random employee.

210
00:12:15.940 --> 00:12:17.990
>> I'll go around and
ask a random person, you're right and

211
00:12:17.990 --> 00:12:20.100
I'll just say where's
your IT security policy?

212
00:12:22.060 --> 00:12:23.090
And if they turn around and

213
00:12:23.090 --> 00:12:26.650
say I don't know or-
>> What is that?

214
00:12:26.650 --> 00:12:29.160
>> Yeah, or what is that, then guess what?

215
00:12:30.260 --> 00:12:33.160
You haven't met one of your
mandatory requirements,

216
00:12:33.160 --> 00:12:36.750
because your mandatory requirement is not
only that you have a security policy but

217
00:12:36.750 --> 00:12:41.100
that it's communicated and
that everybody is fully aware of that.

218
00:12:41.100 --> 00:12:43.280
So management communicate the policy.

219
00:12:43.280 --> 00:12:49.110
And so I'd expect people to know where
the policy is and know how to access it.

220
00:12:50.660 --> 00:12:53.440
Management have got to ensure
those security management

221
00:12:53.440 --> 00:12:55.330
objectives are established.

222
00:12:55.330 --> 00:12:59.100
So it's management's responsibility to
ensure that there are objectives for

223
00:12:59.100 --> 00:13:00.260
security management.

224
00:13:00.260 --> 00:13:05.400
So again, show me, show me the objectives,
show me the approach for managing risks.

225
00:13:05.400 --> 00:13:09.169
Show me what your risk
management methodology is.

226
00:13:09.169 --> 00:13:10.707
Show me how you manage risks.

227
00:13:10.707 --> 00:13:15.150
I want to see evidence that you have
identified security risks in the past,

228
00:13:15.150 --> 00:13:19.522
that you have a mechanism for identifying
security risks in the future and

229
00:13:19.522 --> 00:13:24.270
that you've done something with
the security risks that you've identified.

230
00:13:25.390 --> 00:13:30.700
I want to see evidence that internal
security audits are done and

231
00:13:30.700 --> 00:13:31.920
that are reviewed.

232
00:13:31.920 --> 00:13:33.560
And that there are opportunities for

233
00:13:33.560 --> 00:13:37.450
improvement identified
in your security audits.

234
00:13:37.450 --> 00:13:38.970
Show me.

235
00:13:38.970 --> 00:13:40.263
Show me what you have.

236
00:13:42.060 --> 00:13:45.570
And then we carry on
with security controls.

237
00:13:45.570 --> 00:13:48.800
And again, I'm gonna say the same thing.

238
00:13:48.800 --> 00:13:51.080
Show me, show me the controls.

239
00:13:51.080 --> 00:13:54.810
Show me what you are implementing to,
well,

240
00:13:55.970 --> 00:14:01.450
ensure that you have physical security
that you can preserve the CIA and

241
00:14:01.450 --> 00:14:05.610
that you are upholding all of
the clauses in your security policy and

242
00:14:05.610 --> 00:14:09.980
that you are achieving those objectives
and then you are managing risks.

243
00:14:09.980 --> 00:14:10.480
Show me.

244
00:14:11.760 --> 00:14:16.800
Show me that you're reviewing your
security controls on a regular basis.

245
00:14:16.800 --> 00:14:21.360
And I want to see a list of what
external organizations actually have

246
00:14:21.360 --> 00:14:26.510
access to your IT,
have access to your infrastructure.

247
00:14:26.510 --> 00:14:29.630
Whether they do this on your behalf
because they're managing your

248
00:14:29.630 --> 00:14:30.790
infrastructure or

249
00:14:30.790 --> 00:14:36.720
whether they are doing this because
they are working as a partner with you.

250
00:14:36.720 --> 00:14:40.120
I want to see what access they have.

251
00:14:40.120 --> 00:14:44.270
And I want to see what security
profile you've given them.

252
00:14:44.270 --> 00:14:49.110
So you may use things like
access management as a process.

253
00:14:49.110 --> 00:14:52.090
You may use that to help demonstrate this.

254
00:14:52.090 --> 00:14:53.760
>> Even like Active Directory?

255
00:14:53.760 --> 00:14:55.210
>> Right, yeah.

256
00:14:55.210 --> 00:14:58.310
Active Directory,
that will show me some of this.

257
00:14:58.310 --> 00:15:01.210
It doesn't show me the external
organizations, but

258
00:15:01.210 --> 00:15:03.050
it'll show me that you've
got controls in place.

259
00:15:03.050 --> 00:15:07.280
And it will show me that
you have the control for

260
00:15:07.280 --> 00:15:09.510
external people most definitely.

261
00:15:09.510 --> 00:15:11.030
So yes, that will help.

262
00:15:11.030 --> 00:15:11.930
That will definitely help.

263
00:15:11.930 --> 00:15:17.530
And we've also gotta make sure
that when something happens,

264
00:15:18.885 --> 00:15:23.445
when there is a change to a new service,
when we're bringing in a new service.

265
00:15:23.445 --> 00:15:26.205
Don't forget,
we're in service delivery here.

266
00:15:26.205 --> 00:15:27.875
We're in delivery processes.

267
00:15:27.875 --> 00:15:31.541
So when we're bringing in a new service,
you've got to

268
00:15:31.541 --> 00:15:35.993
show me that that new service has
been assessed for security risks.

269
00:15:35.993 --> 00:15:40.953
And that that new service or
the change to an existing service, well,

270
00:15:40.953 --> 00:15:45.290
that we've considered
security in any change.

271
00:15:45.290 --> 00:15:50.040
And you've also got to show me that
you have a mechanism in place for

272
00:15:50.040 --> 00:15:55.240
dealing with security incidents,
when there is a security breach,

273
00:15:55.240 --> 00:15:57.310
when something goes wrong.

274
00:15:57.310 --> 00:16:01.980
So I want to see you your process
of dealing with security incidents.

275
00:16:01.980 --> 00:16:03.690
I want to see what happens.

276
00:16:03.690 --> 00:16:09.430
I want to see that you have prioritization
set for your security incidents.

277
00:16:09.430 --> 00:16:12.860
I want to see that you're able to
analyze the security incidents.

278
00:16:12.860 --> 00:16:15.870
I want to see how many security
incidents you've had and

279
00:16:15.870 --> 00:16:20.320
I want to see the impact and I want to see
what you've done about it, in other words,

280
00:16:20.320 --> 00:16:22.200
your opportunities for improvement.

281
00:16:23.640 --> 00:16:25.505
I know I sound very needy.

282
00:16:25.505 --> 00:16:30.020
[LAUGH] I carry on sound really
needy throughout through these

283
00:16:30.020 --> 00:16:32.180
particular episodes for ISO 20000.

284
00:16:32.180 --> 00:16:35.161
But essentially I want to see evidence so

285
00:16:35.161 --> 00:16:39.554
yes I sound needy because I want
you to show me what you have.

286
00:16:39.554 --> 00:16:44.666
Okay, so as far as service
delivery processes are concerned,

287
00:16:44.666 --> 00:16:48.430
well, we've now looked at clause six.

288
00:16:48.430 --> 00:16:53.160
And so, when we come back,
we will be looking at our other clauses.

289
00:16:53.160 --> 00:16:58.290
We've still have clauses seven through
clause nine to look at and to analyze and

290
00:16:58.290 --> 00:17:01.230
look at what the requirements
are of these particular clauses.

291
00:17:01.230 --> 00:17:03.780
So we will be doing that
in a subsequent episode.

292
00:17:03.780 --> 00:17:04.481
All right, Jo,

293
00:17:04.481 --> 00:17:08.103
I have a feeling that you're gonna give us
more shalls here with clause number seven.

294
00:17:08.103 --> 00:17:11.190
So ladies and gentlemen,
you don't want to miss those, stay tuned.

295
00:17:11.190 --> 00:17:13.310
But for this show we'll go ahead and
sign out.

296
00:17:13.310 --> 00:17:14.860
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

297
00:17:14.860 --> 00:17:16.375
>> And I'm the needy Jo Peacock.

298
00:17:16.375 --> 00:17:18.760
>> [LAUGH] See you next time, bye.

299
00:17:18.760 --> 00:17:25.359
[MUSIC]

300
00:17:25.359 --> 00:17:27.711
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo begin explaining the relationship processes. The ladies demonstrate how the relationship processes are responsible for managing the relationships with other parties.  Jo shares how the business relationship management (BRM) process aims to establish and maintain the relationship between the service provider and the customer(s).  They also discuss how the supplier management process is responsible for managing suppliers to ensure the provision of seamless, quality services.
episodes.title: Clause 7 - Relationship Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.583
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:03.583 --> 00:00:05.462
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.462 --> 00:00:07.800
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.800 --> 00:00:10.246
>> You're watching, ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.246 --> 00:00:18.970
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to your
ISO/IEC 20000:2011 Foundation series.

6
00:00:18.970 --> 00:00:21.110
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:21.110 --> 00:00:24.430
In this episode, we're gonna be
picking up here with clause seven,

8
00:00:24.430 --> 00:00:26.370
really looking at relationship processes.

9
00:00:26.370 --> 00:00:31.310
Back in studios with us today,
we have ISO expert, Mrs. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:31.310 --> 00:00:32.490
How's it going Jo?

11
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:35.417
>> Absolutely great, Cherokee,
and I'm so pleased to be here.

12
00:00:35.417 --> 00:00:39.170
>> Yeah, me too, I mean, we're looking
at relationship processes here.

13
00:00:39.170 --> 00:00:44.330
We're definitely not gonna be giving
out any dating advice, right?

14
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:45.505
>> Not in this show, anyway.

15
00:00:45.505 --> 00:00:47.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> Maybe in another show.

16
00:00:47.100 --> 00:00:49.670
Yes, this is not the channel for this.

17
00:00:49.670 --> 00:00:52.800
>> So what specifically are we talking
about when we say relationship?

18
00:00:52.800 --> 00:00:55.570
Relationships between
different department,

19
00:00:55.570 --> 00:00:58.920
relationships with our customers,
our businesses?

20
00:00:58.920 --> 00:01:00.860
>> Well, let's take a look at the slide,
shall we?

21
00:01:00.860 --> 00:01:02.470
Here's one I prepared earlier.

22
00:01:04.540 --> 00:01:07.400
Here's not one that I prepared earlier,
there we go, it's there,

23
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:09.600
I knew it was there somewhere, hidden.

24
00:01:09.600 --> 00:01:11.835
It's a very shy relationship,
in this case.

25
00:01:11.835 --> 00:01:13.980
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're looking at actually

26
00:01:13.980 --> 00:01:15.750
the relationship with our business, and

27
00:01:15.750 --> 00:01:18.980
we're also looking at the relationship
with our suppliers, as well.

28
00:01:18.980 --> 00:01:22.786
So, we're looking actually at
relationships outside of IT.

29
00:01:22.786 --> 00:01:24.468
And in ISO 20000,

30
00:01:24.468 --> 00:01:29.610
we want to make sure that you actually
have relationships outside of IT.

31
00:01:29.610 --> 00:01:33.715
And that you're able to manage them
in an efficient and an effective way.

32
00:01:33.715 --> 00:01:34.631
In other words,

33
00:01:34.631 --> 00:01:39.010
we don't want an IT service provider
that's working in a complete silo.

34
00:01:39.010 --> 00:01:42.510
That has no interaction with the business,
no interaction with suppliers.

35
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:43.800
>> And Cortana doesn't count.

36
00:01:45.503 --> 00:01:46.890
>> Who on earth is that?

37
00:01:46.890 --> 00:01:49.060
Are you talking about Siri?

38
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:51.770
Siri's nemesis.

39
00:01:51.770 --> 00:01:53.812
>> Really, I'm not that good a nemesis,
cuz I don't--

40
00:01:53.812 --> 00:01:54.503
>> [LAUGH]

41
00:01:54.503 --> 00:01:56.811
>> Think anybody else has ever heard of

42
00:01:56.811 --> 00:01:57.503
them, right.

43
00:01:57.503 --> 00:01:58.400
[LAUGH]
>> Okay.

44
00:01:58.400 --> 00:02:03.140
>> No, Cortana doesn't count, but
I'm sure there was a movie about that.

45
00:02:04.430 --> 00:02:05.100
Yes there was.

46
00:02:05.100 --> 00:02:06.210
>> Yeah, you told me about that.

47
00:02:06.210 --> 00:02:08.450
>> Yes, some.
>> Where they had, yes.

48
00:02:08.450 --> 00:02:10.270
>> Let's carry on.
>> An AI relationship, so

49
00:02:10.270 --> 00:02:11.220
that doesn't count.

50
00:02:11.220 --> 00:02:13.040
[LAUGH]
>> Let's move on, please.

51
00:02:13.040 --> 00:02:14.010
>> Okay, shall we?

52
00:02:14.010 --> 00:02:16.364
>> Yeah,
let's talk about real relationships here.

53
00:02:17.390 --> 00:02:19.367
Before we delve too much
into your psyche [LAUGH].

54
00:02:21.100 --> 00:02:23.340
Let's take a look at business
relationship management,

55
00:02:23.340 --> 00:02:25.380
now let's see what we're going to test.

56
00:02:25.380 --> 00:02:30.030
And we're not just going to test that
you know how to talk to Siri, or

57
00:02:30.030 --> 00:02:32.120
Cortana, or Watson.

58
00:02:32.120 --> 00:02:33.985
Let's be completely impartial here.

59
00:02:33.985 --> 00:02:36.780
>> Okay.
>> What we're actually going to do is

60
00:02:36.780 --> 00:02:41.660
we're going to test that you're
able to talk to your business.

61
00:02:41.660 --> 00:02:44.390
And you are able to talk
the same languages your business.

62
00:02:44.390 --> 00:02:45.900
Because that can be a challenge, as well.

63
00:02:45.900 --> 00:02:48.930
And that you are able to talk
to your suppliers, as well.

64
00:02:48.930 --> 00:02:53.788
So we have requirements, and requirements
for business relationship management.

65
00:02:53.788 --> 00:02:57.021
These are your you have
to show me evidence of

66
00:02:57.021 --> 00:03:00.470
the fact that you know
who your customers are.

67
00:03:00.470 --> 00:03:03.950
And who your users are, and
who your stakeholders are.

68
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:06.135
In other words, any interested party.

69
00:03:07.660 --> 00:03:12.261
You have to show me evidence that not only
do you have maybe a CRM, for instance.

70
00:03:12.261 --> 00:03:15.800
That will help you,
Customer Relationship Management Database.

71
00:03:15.800 --> 00:03:20.160
But you also have to show me
who your customer contact is.

72
00:03:21.510 --> 00:03:27.140
It should be an individual
within your team, within IT,

73
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:33.260
who is going to manage the relationship
between IT and the customer.

74
00:03:33.260 --> 00:03:35.480
So you have to know who your customer is,
but

75
00:03:35.480 --> 00:03:40.910
you also have to have somebody
assigned to manage that relationship.

76
00:03:40.910 --> 00:03:46.060
Now, this is ISO 20000, so
we don't care what you call him.

77
00:03:46.060 --> 00:03:49.290
You could call him or her,
the business relationship manager, or

78
00:03:49.290 --> 00:03:50.640
you could call him Fred.

79
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:54.311
We're not really bothered about what you
call him and what label you give him.

80
00:03:54.311 --> 00:03:59.224
We want to know that you have got
a designated somebody to managed that

81
00:03:59.224 --> 00:04:01.210
relationship.

82
00:04:01.210 --> 00:04:06.660
We also want to see a visible,
defined communication mechanism for

83
00:04:06.660 --> 00:04:08.910
how to communicate with the customer.

84
00:04:08.910 --> 00:04:12.500
How we gain information
back from the customer.

85
00:04:12.500 --> 00:04:16.400
And, how we gain information
regarding new requirements.

86
00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:20.530
And also,
how we feedback to the customer, as well.

87
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:25.090
So I want to see evidence
of where you have

88
00:04:25.090 --> 00:04:30.270
taken information from the customer, and
what you've done with that information.

89
00:04:30.270 --> 00:04:33.020
Maybe it's in a CRM,
