00:16:52.965 --> 00:16:57.234
You see, so this is why we've
got to get to that point.

322
00:16:57.234 --> 00:17:02.400
This is why business relationship
management is so key, and this is why you

323
00:17:02.400 --> 00:17:07.652
have to have somebody that then picks up
the piece of paper at the end of this.

324
00:17:07.652 --> 00:17:11.205
You have to have somebody that then
contacts that particular person, or

325
00:17:11.205 --> 00:17:15.240
maybe the customer, the person who's paid
the bill, and say, do you know what?

326
00:17:15.240 --> 00:17:18.660
I saw that Cherokee attended
one of Jo's classes, and

327
00:17:18.660 --> 00:17:21.260
she wasn't particularly happy with Jo.

328
00:17:21.260 --> 00:17:22.542
Can you tell me a little
bit more about this?

329
00:17:22.542 --> 00:17:27.590
Can you tell me what it was
that she didn't like too much?

330
00:17:27.590 --> 00:17:29.960
What was it that she
didn't mesh too well with?

331
00:17:31.290 --> 00:17:35.910
We have to have that agreement between
what is a complaint and how we follow this

332
00:17:35.910 --> 00:17:40.042
up, and when it comes to an audit I
wanna see that you've got in place.

333
00:17:40.042 --> 00:17:42.420
I want to see that you know
how to deal with that.

334
00:17:42.420 --> 00:17:43.300
>> Okay.

335
00:17:43.300 --> 00:17:44.596
>> And that's not something that,

336
00:17:44.596 --> 00:17:47.290
you might think to yourself,
well that's actually quite small.

337
00:17:47.290 --> 00:17:49.590
It's not really something
that we need to worry about.

338
00:17:49.590 --> 00:17:52.669
Well it is because it's in
here in Part 1 as a shall.

339
00:17:52.669 --> 00:17:55.450
You've got to do this, so yes it is.

340
00:17:55.450 --> 00:17:58.820
We have to have a documented procedure for

341
00:17:58.820 --> 00:18:02.050
what we're going to do
with that information.

342
00:18:02.050 --> 00:18:06.120
Because whether we've treated it as
a complaint or whether we've treat it

343
00:18:06.120 --> 00:18:10.230
just as an observation,
well that will then decide whether it goes

344
00:18:10.230 --> 00:18:14.690
down the complaints process or whether
it just gets logged as an observation.

345
00:18:14.690 --> 00:18:17.880
That will decide as to whether
it's been escalated or not.

346
00:18:17.880 --> 00:18:20.340
Does that need escalation?

347
00:18:20.340 --> 00:18:24.778
A formal complaint will need escalation,
but will that actually need an escalation?

348
00:18:26.870 --> 00:18:32.270
The thing is that you have to agree with
the customer as to what is considered

349
00:18:32.270 --> 00:18:38.380
a complaint and what is considered
a observation, cuz this service provider,

350
00:18:38.380 --> 00:18:41.370
I'm the one delivering a training course
and Cherokee's the one paying, and

351
00:18:41.370 --> 00:18:44.308
she's paid for all of her team
to attend that training course.

352
00:18:44.308 --> 00:18:47.655
Now, I'm gonna ask another question.

353
00:18:47.655 --> 00:18:49.800
Let's say we dealt with
that as a complaint.

354
00:18:51.280 --> 00:18:54.648
That means that I'm gonna be calling
you up and I'm gonna be saying to you,

355
00:18:54.648 --> 00:18:58.070
right I've spoken to Jo about her
performance, and so what we've agreed is

356
00:18:58.070 --> 00:19:01.514
that Jo will come back and she'll work
with that person on a one to one basis.

357
00:19:01.514 --> 00:19:04.740
You might turn around and say, actually,
I don't want any of this hassle.

358
00:19:04.740 --> 00:19:07.100
The person got the training course,
they passed their test,

359
00:19:07.100 --> 00:19:08.180
that's all I'm interested in.

360
00:19:10.720 --> 00:19:13.867
So that again, might influence us to
whether we deal with that as a complaint

361
00:19:13.867 --> 00:19:16.940
or whether we deal with that
as just an observation.

362
00:19:16.940 --> 00:19:20.610
So maybe the question that you have to ask
yourself is, do I need to follow this up,

363
00:19:20.610 --> 00:19:22.070
yes or no?

364
00:19:22.070 --> 00:19:25.450
Because if you don't need to follow it up
then it shouldn't be a complaint, perhaps.

365
00:19:26.720 --> 00:19:31.450
I don't know, it's your organization,
only you know, but

366
00:19:31.450 --> 00:19:34.690
I'm gonna check that you have got
a mechanism in place to do that.

367
00:19:36.090 --> 00:19:41.034
I don't know how you do it, but I'm gonna
check that you have got a mechanism

368
00:19:41.034 --> 00:19:45.975
in place, and so we apply the same sort
of principles when we look at supplier

369
00:19:45.975 --> 00:19:50.997
management, and supplier management
is all about managing our suppliers,

370
00:19:50.997 --> 00:19:55.200
and it says that about provision
of seamless quality services.

371
00:19:55.200 --> 00:19:59.553
This doesn't include supply selection and
procurement either,

372
00:19:59.553 --> 00:20:04.090
because that is done very uniquely
within every organization.

373
00:20:04.090 --> 00:20:08.081
It's down to your organization and to
your organizational ethics as to how you

374
00:20:08.081 --> 00:20:10.317
procure and
as to how you select suppliers,

375
00:20:10.317 --> 00:20:14.680
whether you go out to tend the process or
whether you have preferred suppliers, etc.

376
00:20:14.680 --> 00:20:20.986
What we can tell you is, what we deal
with is what's inside that dotted line.

377
00:20:20.986 --> 00:20:23.410
So we'll deal with the suppliers.

378
00:20:23.410 --> 00:20:26.177
We will manage the suppliers.

379
00:20:26.177 --> 00:20:32.750
We will not manage the relationship
directly with the subcontracted suppliers.

380
00:20:32.750 --> 00:20:36.360
That is down to Supplier B
in this particular diagram.

381
00:20:36.360 --> 00:20:40.463
Supplier B manages
the subcontracted suppliers.

382
00:20:40.463 --> 00:20:42.220
We do not do that directly.

383
00:20:42.220 --> 00:20:46.660
So we will not be auditing that you have
a relationship with your subcontracted

384
00:20:46.660 --> 00:20:50.350
suppliers, because that's really
down to Supplier B to do that.

385
00:20:50.350 --> 00:20:54.460
What we will check is that
somebody will take ownership for

386
00:20:54.460 --> 00:20:59.300
supplier management,
either you have contracts in place or

387
00:20:59.300 --> 00:21:02.790
that you have service level
targets within those contracts.

388
00:21:02.790 --> 00:21:06.610
You may have penalties and incentives.

389
00:21:06.610 --> 00:21:10.130
All changes to the contract have to
go through change management, and

390
00:21:10.130 --> 00:21:14.630
there has to be a documented dispute
procedure as well for all contracts,

391
00:21:15.950 --> 00:21:19.090
and where we have a situation where
we've got lead suppliers then we've got

392
00:21:19.090 --> 00:21:24.020
subcontractors, we've got to make sure
that the roles and responsibilities,

393
00:21:24.020 --> 00:21:29.280
in other words, where the buck stops,
as we like to say, is defined.

394
00:21:29.280 --> 00:21:34.037
So we want to ensure that the lead
suppliers manage their subcontractors, but

395
00:21:34.037 --> 00:21:36.425
how they do that is entirely up to them.

396
00:21:36.425 --> 00:21:40.981
We have to monitor performance against
our contract, and against those service

397
00:21:40.981 --> 00:21:44.742
targets, and then we have to do
something with that performance.

398
00:21:44.742 --> 00:21:47.510
We've got to review the results and
do something with it.

399
00:21:47.510 --> 00:21:49.690
So I wanna see evidence of that.

400
00:21:49.690 --> 00:21:54.750
I also want to see evidence
that contracts are reviewed on

401
00:21:54.750 --> 00:22:00.490
a regular basis, and I will tell
you that any documentation really,

402
00:22:00.490 --> 00:22:05.180
and it should, it should be reviewed,
at least once a year, but we wanna see

403
00:22:05.180 --> 00:22:10.900
evidence that reviews have taken place,
and that's what we want to see.

404
00:22:10.900 --> 00:22:14.330
We want to see that reviews have happened.

405
00:22:14.330 --> 00:22:17.660
We need to see documentary evidence.

406
00:22:17.660 --> 00:22:20.080
As always, I'm always gonna say, show me.

407
00:22:22.018 --> 00:22:26.675
So now we've finished looking at
our relationship processes, and

408
00:22:26.675 --> 00:22:32.328
in our next episode, we are going to be
taking a look at our resolution processes.

409
00:22:32.328 --> 00:22:36.866
But for now, we would just like you
to review on what we've covered so

410
00:22:36.866 --> 00:22:41.873
far and if you have any queries, obviously
then come back to us on the forum,

411
00:22:41.873 --> 00:22:46.445
and we'll be happy to help wherever
we can, and we'll say goodbye.

412
00:22:46.445 --> 00:22:49.402
>> All right, and don't forget
to go ahead and use those stars.

413
00:22:49.402 --> 00:22:51.945
>> [LAUGH]
>> But thank you so much for

414
00:22:51.945 --> 00:22:53.505
being with us, and like Jo said,

415
00:22:53.505 --> 00:22:56.635
stay tuned we've got clause 8 coming up,
so you don't wanna miss that.

416
00:22:56.635 --> 00:22:58.966
But for this show we'll go ahead and
sign out.

417
00:22:58.966 --> 00:23:00.426
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

418
00:23:00.426 --> 00:23:01.668
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

419
00:23:01.668 --> 00:23:03.590
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

420
00:23:03.590 --> 00:23:06.653
[MUSIC]

421
00:23:06.653 --> 00:23:11.933
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee introduce incident and service request management. They explain how it differs from problem management. Key terminology is defined in addition to examples such as a Matrix of target times based on priorities .
episodes.title: Clause 8 - Resolution Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.674
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pazet.

2
00:00:02.674 --> 00:00:06.595
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.595 --> 00:00:08.364
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.364 --> 00:00:12.196
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.196 --> 00:00:18.105
>> Welcome back to your ISO/IEC
20000:2011 Foundation series.

6
00:00:18.105 --> 00:00:20.500
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.500 --> 00:00:23.642
In this episode we'll be taking
a look at clause eight and

8
00:00:23.642 --> 00:00:27.060
specifically will be talking
about a resolution processes.

9
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:32.680
Back in studios with us today we have
ISO expert Jo Peacock, hows it going Jo?

10
00:00:32.680 --> 00:00:34.950
>> Absolutely great thank
you Cherokee how are you?

11
00:00:34.950 --> 00:00:38.770
>> I'm good and we're not having any
kind of conflict resolution, but

12
00:00:38.770 --> 00:00:42.590
if we were, then, would this be
the episode we would talk about that?

13
00:00:43.710 --> 00:00:47.130
>> I think that there's a special couch
waiting for us to talk about that.

14
00:00:47.130 --> 00:00:48.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't think that we need to do it

15
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:51.680
live on TV, but if you're insisting.

16
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:56.300
Yeah we're talking about picking out
the pieces when something's gone wrong.

17
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:58.140
>> Okay.
>> That's what we're talking about.

18
00:00:58.140 --> 00:01:00.050
We're not talking about
too much about conflict,

19
00:01:00.050 --> 00:01:02.320
we dealt with that in resolution.

20
00:01:02.320 --> 00:01:06.260
We're just talking about when something
goes wrong, well picking up the pieces and

21
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:08.560
also trying to prevent
it from happening again.

22
00:01:08.560 --> 00:01:09.340
>> Okay.

23
00:01:09.340 --> 00:01:13.770
>> So here we are in our,
well, resolution processes.

24
00:01:13.770 --> 00:01:16.610
And for those of you that
are familiar with ITIL and

25
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:20.570
I'd imagine a lot of you are, you will
notice that my resolution processes,

26
00:01:20.570 --> 00:01:22.620
that's the yellow at the bottom there.

27
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:25.350
We've got incident and
service request management.

28
00:01:25.350 --> 00:01:28.160
Now that has been combined into
what looks like one process.

29
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:32.910
And we've also got problem
management as well, don't be fooled

30
00:01:32.910 --> 00:01:37.340
by the fact that things have been combined
into what looks like one process.

31
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:39.620
We're talking here about
audit requirements.

32
00:01:39.620 --> 00:01:43.560
And we're talking about what
we are going to audit against,

33
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:46.640
we're not necessarily talking
about separate processes.

34
00:01:46.640 --> 00:01:50.250
This is just this is how we audit,
that's all this is.

35
00:01:50.250 --> 00:01:53.940
So we've got some terms that
I just need you to know.

36
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:58.942
An incident is an unplanned interruption
to or a reduction in the quality

37
00:01:58.942 --> 00:02:03.539
of a service, or it's an event
that not yet impacted the service.

38
00:02:03.539 --> 00:02:08.333
A service request is a request for
information or access to a service or

39
00:02:08.333 --> 00:02:10.340
pre-approved change.

40
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:13.852
And I like to put that into
the category of can I have something or

41
00:02:13.852 --> 00:02:15.388
can you tell me something?

42
00:02:15.388 --> 00:02:20.431
So a problem is the unknown underlying
root cause of one or more incidents.

43
00:02:20.431 --> 00:02:25.742
And a known error is a problem
where we know the root cause but

44
00:02:25.742 --> 00:02:29.920
we have a work around to restore service.

45
00:02:29.920 --> 00:02:34.204
So a known error is a problem for
which a root cause is known and

46
00:02:34.204 --> 00:02:35.803
a work around exists.

47
00:02:35.803 --> 00:02:41.093
So in terms of then the actual
audit itself, ISO 20,000.

48
00:02:41.093 --> 00:02:42.380
What are we auditing against?

49
00:02:42.380 --> 00:02:47.100
What are we looking for
in our resolution processes?

50
00:02:47.100 --> 00:02:50.360
Well, here are our Part 1 Shalls for

51
00:02:50.360 --> 00:02:53.990
incident management,
service request management.

52
00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:56.210
And in incident service
request management,

53
00:02:56.210 --> 00:03:01.090
I am looking to see
documented procedures for

54
00:03:01.090 --> 00:03:06.430
all incidents, and for
the managing of all service requests.

55
00:03:08.180 --> 00:03:12.580
I want to know what you're doing to
make sure that they are all logged.

56
00:03:13.580 --> 00:03:17.820
And I want to make sure that all incidents
and all service requests are logged and

57
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:19.560
that they are all progressed.

58
00:03:19.560 --> 00:03:24.290
So I want to see evidence that you
are setting priority for incidents and for

59
00:03:24.290 --> 00:03:26.879
service requests based on impact and
urgency.

60
00:03:27.890 --> 00:03:31.700
I want to see procedures for
escalation of incidents.

61
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:36.420
I want to see that you have access
to information for your analysts.

62
00:03:36.420 --> 00:03:39.140
Whatever analysts,
whether they be service desk analysts, or

63
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:42.130
super users, or
second level support analysts.

64
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:45.820
Whomever is performing incident and
request management.

65
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:51.230
So, I want to see evidence that they
can access the known error databases.

66
00:03:51.230 --> 00:03:55.090
Problem resolutions, and
your configuration management database.

67
00:03:55.090 --> 00:03:59.460
That they can access releases,
they can access changes, so

68
00:03:59.460 --> 00:04:03.040
that that can help them
with incident resolution.

69
00:04:04.065 --> 00:04:07.515
You see, what we want to do, our intent
here and what we should be doing,

70
00:04:07.515 --> 00:04:11.505
is to manage incidents and
service requests consistently.

71
00:04:11.505 --> 00:04:13.905
To ensure that incident resolution or

72
00:04:13.905 --> 00:04:18.965
request fulfillment is achieved within
the agreed targets and time frames.

73
00:04:18.965 --> 00:04:24.440
Very similar to previous episodes where
we've said that when it comes to targets,

74
00:04:24.440 --> 00:04:29.000
we can't put them in the shall because we
don't always achieve all of our targets.

75
00:04:29.000 --> 00:04:33.270
So this is just in an intent, this is
a should, we should receive all of that,

76
00:04:33.270 --> 00:04:35.380
we should achieve all of our targets.

77
00:04:35.380 --> 00:04:38.890
But as we know, the real world
gets in the way sometimes and

78
00:04:38.890 --> 00:04:41.310
we can't always achieve
all of our targets.

79
00:04:43.240 --> 00:04:46.620
Very simply,
I want an incident to look like this.

80
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:50.500
Very, very simply,
we log it in our core login system.

81
00:04:50.500 --> 00:04:51.730
We classify it, and

82
00:04:51.730 --> 00:04:55.800
we allocate a priority based on impact and
urgency, and we might escalate.

83
00:04:55.800 --> 00:04:59.550
And we can either escalate to
maybe a second level support team,

84
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:01.110
a functional type escalation.

85
00:05:01.110 --> 00:05:05.410
Or that we can escalate to management,
a hierarchical type escalation.

86
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:07.600
And then we will work on the incident.

87
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:12.740
Either we implement a workaround, or
maybe we actually do something else that

88
00:05:12.740 --> 00:05:17.860
will fix the incident, in other words,
restore service operation.

89
00:05:18.960 --> 00:05:23.480
So we resolve that, we confirm with
the user that it's been resolved and

90
00:05:23.480 --> 00:05:25.200
we close the incident.

91
00:05:25.200 --> 00:05:27.840
And I wanna see evidence
when we're auditing.

92
00:05:27.840 --> 00:05:32.190
I want to see evidence
of each one of these.

93
00:05:32.190 --> 00:05:37.580
I want to see that each step has been
fulfilled, this is what I want to see.

94
00:05:37.580 --> 00:05:44.280
And as I said, we base priority on
impact and urgency, I want to see this.

95
00:05:44.280 --> 00:05:48.440
Now, it doesn't mean that I want to see
this in our incident management core login

96
00:05:48.440 --> 00:05:50.932
system, although I'd
expect it to be in there.

97
00:05:50.932 --> 00:05:54.446
And I'd expect it to be managed
by the core log in system but

98
00:05:54.446 --> 00:05:58.950
I'd like to see this in maybe our
service level agreement document.

99
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:03.420
It should be in there, we should
understand what constitutes a priority one

100
00:06:03.420 --> 00:06:08.730
and how quickly we're going to aim
to resolve a priority one incident.

101
00:06:08.730 --> 00:06:12.490
I want to see this in a service
level agreement document.

102
00:06:13.720 --> 00:06:19.900
I also want to see a method for
handling major incidents.

103
00:06:19.900 --> 00:06:24.040
I want to see that we have a definition
for what constitutes a major incident, and

104
00:06:24.040 --> 00:06:28.410
I want to see that this is
agreed with the customer.

105
00:06:28.410 --> 00:06:31.717
That we've got a procedure,
that it is documented,

106
00:06:31.717 --> 00:06:35.905
that it's agreed with the customer,
and that senior management or

107
00:06:35.905 --> 00:06:39.151
top management,
as we call it in ISO 20,000.

108
00:06:39.151 --> 00:06:45.530
Will allocate a defined individual to
be responsible for any major incident.

109
00:06:46.690 --> 00:06:51.420
So I want to know what the difference
is between a priority one incident and

110
00:06:51.420 --> 00:06:53.110
a major incident.

111
00:06:53.110 --> 00:06:57.910
I also wan to know at what point
in time do we hand over a major

112
00:06:57.910 --> 00:07:00.370
incident to service continuity.

113
00:07:00.370 --> 00:07:06.250
At what point in time do we start as
we called in a previous episode or

114
00:07:06.250 --> 00:07:09.960
as Cherokee referred to it in
a previous episode, disaster recovery.

115
00:07:09.960 --> 00:07:11.340
At what point in time?

116
00:07:11.340 --> 00:07:14.599
There's an overlap there and
I want to see those relationships.

117
00:07:15.720 --> 00:07:20.413
I also want to see that after a major
incident once service has been restored

118
00:07:20.413 --> 00:07:24.525
then I want to see that a review
is conducted for a major incident.

119
00:07:24.525 --> 00:07:28.822
So I want to see not only evidence
of the actual process itself, but

120
00:07:28.822 --> 00:07:34.136
I also want to see evidence that reviews
have been happening for major incidents.

121
00:07:34.136 --> 00:07:37.560
So me show me,
show me that reviews have been happening.

122
00:07:38.880 --> 00:07:39.760
We have to think about,

123
00:07:39.760 --> 00:07:45.270
I've just mentioned two relationships
in the last couple of seconds.

124
00:07:45.270 --> 00:07:49.791
I mentioned the relationship with service
level management when we talked about

125
00:07:49.791 --> 00:07:50.796
the priorities.

126
00:07:50.796 --> 00:07:55.065
I also mentioned
the relationship with service

127
00:07:55.065 --> 00:07:59.228
continuity management
when we talked about,

128
00:07:59.228 --> 00:08:04.149
when does a major incident
become a continuity issue.

129
00:08:04.149 --> 00:08:12.495
There are lots of examples of
when processes work together.

130
00:08:12.495 --> 00:08:14.435
And we want to see evidence
of those examples,

131
00:08:14.435 --> 00:08:16.840
we want to see evidence of
when processes work together.

132
00:08:16.840 --> 00:08:19.696
Let me give you a very,
very brief example.

133
00:08:19.696 --> 00:08:22.260
Service level management,
within service level management

134
00:08:23.620 --> 00:08:27.780
we define targets within our
service level agreements.

135
00:08:27.780 --> 00:08:32.710
But we also have hours of
operation as well for a service.

136
00:08:32.710 --> 00:08:36.420
Now you will notice in previous
episodes that the hours of operation

137
00:08:36.420 --> 00:08:39.950
were also displayed in
the catalog of services.

138
00:08:39.950 --> 00:08:44.690
So in our catalog we will see the service
description that's come from service level

139
00:08:44.690 --> 00:08:50.240
management and the hours of operation,
that's come from service level management.

140
00:08:50.240 --> 00:08:51.800
And also who the customer is.

141
00:08:51.800 --> 00:08:54.710
That's the person that's signed the SLA.

142
00:08:54.710 --> 00:08:57.450
So again,
that's come from service level management.

143
00:08:57.450 --> 00:09:01.510
So we'll see that, but
then all of those hours of operation and

144
00:09:01.510 --> 00:09:04.804
those targets will be fed
into incident management.

145
00:09:04.804 --> 00:09:07.250
And incident management will

146
00:09:07.250 --> 00:09:12.160
restore service as per the targets
that are outlined in the SLA.

147
00:09:12.160 --> 00:09:16.690
But they will also, as per any targets
that maybe outlined in the SLA,

148
00:09:16.690 --> 00:09:21.330
raise a problem to identify the root cause
of an incident, should they need to.

149
00:09:21.330 --> 00:09:26.770
And again, that problem will be progressed
as per the targets outlined in the SLA.

150
00:09:26.770 --> 00:09:31.150
We may also need to raise
a change to resolve a problem.

151
00:09:31.150 --> 00:09:36.060
And if we raise that request for change,
again, we'll be progressing that change

152
00:09:36.060 --> 00:09:40.330
record through using targets
that are defined in the SLA.

153
00:09:41.370 --> 00:09:46.520
So here's a huge big chain of
command as we might call it there.

154
00:09:46.520 --> 00:09:49.600
There's a huge big change,
all of those relationships.

155
00:09:49.600 --> 00:09:52.400
Now, I've already mentioned
a relationship between incident and

156
00:09:52.400 --> 00:09:54.290
service continuity management.

157
00:09:54.290 --> 00:09:56.970
But what about things like
availability management,

158
00:09:56.970 --> 00:09:59.300
capacity management and
problem management?

159
00:10:00.380 --> 00:10:03.750
Problem management, well,
it's split into two.

160
00:10:03.750 --> 00:10:07.831
It's about responding to and
finding root causes for incidents.

161
00:10:07.831 --> 00:10:10.933
It's also about preventing
incidents from happening.

162
00:10:10.933 --> 00:10:15.673
In which case, if we're preventing
incidents from happening then we are doing

163
00:10:15.673 --> 00:10:20.627
a risk management and risk management also
falls into availability management and

164
00:10:20.627 --> 00:10:24.892
service continuity management and
into capacity management as well.

165
00:10:24.892 --> 00:10:31.051
Where we're identifying potential impacts
of changes on capacity requirements and

166
00:10:31.051 --> 00:10:36.020
on availability requirements
because they could cause incidents.

167
00:10:36.020 --> 00:10:38.308
In other words,
they could become problems.

168
00:10:38.308 --> 00:10:43.270
Loss of relationships,

169
00:10:43.270 --> 00:10:47.730
when you actually see a relationship
diagram full of the processes that

170
00:10:47.730 --> 00:10:53.140
are within IT service management itself,

171
00:10:53.140 --> 00:10:55.820
it kind of looks like a spider
has crawled across the page.

172
00:10:57.030 --> 00:10:57.880
It really does.

173
00:10:57.880 --> 00:11:01.300
Because there are relationships
with every single activity and

174
00:11:01.300 --> 00:11:04.750
process that we do within
IT service management.

175
00:11:06.220 --> 00:11:09.276
We wanna see evidence of those
relationships being documented.

176
00:11:09.276 --> 00:11:13.353
And there are lots of useful information,
we call it, sort of,

177
00:11:13.353 --> 00:11:18.578
complimentary guidance and we mentioned
it in our introduction to ISO 2000.

178
00:11:18.578 --> 00:11:22.643
There's lots of information out there and
lots of images and

179
00:11:22.643 --> 00:11:27.507
lots of graphical representations out
there of all of the relationships

180
00:11:27.507 --> 00:11:31.029
between processes within
IT services management.

181
00:11:32.570 --> 00:11:35.705
They can help you by showing
you what we're looking for.

182
00:11:35.705 --> 00:11:39.470
I can't provide you with the evidence,
but they can help

183
00:11:39.470 --> 00:11:42.820
you by showing you what you're
looking for, and certainly your tools.

184
00:11:42.820 --> 00:11:45.390
Your workflow process engines,
as we like to call it.

185
00:11:45.390 --> 00:11:48.890
I think you called it a ticketing system,
didn't you, in one previous episode?

186
00:11:48.890 --> 00:11:49.730
>> Yeah, I did.

187
00:11:49.730 --> 00:11:52.190
>> Yeah, we like to call that
a workflow process engine.

188
00:11:52.190 --> 00:11:52.810
>> Okay.

189
00:11:52.810 --> 00:11:55.045
>> Yeah, it's one extreme to
the other that is, isn't it?

190
00:11:55.045 --> 00:11:57.681
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, mine is totally informal,

191
00:11:57.681 --> 00:11:59.430
that's the correct terminology.

192
00:11:59.430 --> 00:12:04.487
>> Yeah, that will sort of provide you
with a lot of help certainly in terms

193
00:12:04.487 --> 00:12:09.568
of evidence, in terms of being able
to articulate the relationships.

194
00:12:09.568 --> 00:12:13.840
Cuz quite often it's difficult to say,
well look, this is definitely happening.

195
00:12:13.840 --> 00:12:15.230
And of course, what we want to see,

196
00:12:15.230 --> 00:12:18.770
is we want to see evidence that
these relationships are in place.

197
00:12:18.770 --> 00:12:22.500
And so, you can't just print
off a relationship diagram.

198
00:12:22.500 --> 00:12:25.610
And even then a relationship diagram
doesn't prove that the relationships

199
00:12:25.610 --> 00:12:29.678
are in place, it's just a demonstration
of what relationships should look like.

200
00:12:29.678 --> 00:12:34.400
So yes, you use your tool,
your tool will help you with this.

201
00:12:34.400 --> 00:12:37.790
But also use information that is
available out there in the big,

202
00:12:37.790 --> 00:12:42.170
wide world, on that big,
wide web as it were.

203
00:12:42.170 --> 00:12:45.660
That will help you certainly,
so let's look at problem

204
00:12:45.660 --> 00:12:49.105
management because we've already spoken
a little bit about problem management.

205
00:12:49.105 --> 00:12:52.130
Problem management well,
their role, obviously,

206
00:12:52.130 --> 00:12:54.960
is to identifying then the root causes.

207
00:12:54.960 --> 00:12:59.530
So we're identifying problems here and
we're avoiding the impact of incidence.

208
00:12:59.530 --> 00:13:01.760
So we're trying to prevent incidence.

209
00:13:01.760 --> 00:13:05.960
So, again, I want to see evidence
that we're recording problems.

210
00:13:05.960 --> 00:13:09.110
That we're given problems,
priorities, escalation,

211
00:13:09.110 --> 00:13:12.230
that we have escalation procedures
in place they'e being updated.

212
00:13:12.230 --> 00:13:17.860
That we're raising an RFC, a request for
change, if we need to raise a change.

213
00:13:17.860 --> 00:13:22.239
And that we are subject to
continual improvement for

214
00:13:22.239 --> 00:13:25.135
our problem management process.

215
00:13:25.135 --> 00:13:29.693
The intent is that we identify the unknown
underlying root cause of one or

216
00:13:29.693 --> 00:13:30.823
more incidents.

217
00:13:30.823 --> 00:13:34.812
And that we actually are able
to affect resolutions

218
00:13:34.812 --> 00:13:39.300
to those root causes through
change management, okay.

219
00:13:39.300 --> 00:13:42.770
But proactively, we also have to
prevent incidents from occurring.

220
00:13:42.770 --> 00:13:46.480
Now again, we're not going to do
this in every single incidence.

221
00:13:46.480 --> 00:13:52.360
So what I'm expecting is I'm expecting
to see evidence in the Shall.

222
00:13:52.360 --> 00:13:56.530
I'm expecting to see evidence
where we can analyze information.

223
00:13:56.530 --> 00:14:01.290
I'm expecting to see evidence where
we have identified root causes.

224
00:14:01.290 --> 00:14:06.350
And where we've made decisions on
the fact that we are not resolving.

225
00:14:06.350 --> 00:14:10.510
Sometimes we don't always want to
resolve a problem, and that's okay.

226
00:14:10.510 --> 00:14:14.380
We may choose that we don't wanna resolve
a problem because maybe it costs too much.

227
00:14:14.380 --> 00:14:18.080
Or maybe that service is about to be
retired, or maybe it's a strategic or

228
00:14:18.080 --> 00:14:22.340
a business decision not to
resolve that particular problem.

229
00:14:22.340 --> 00:14:27.100
That's okay, but we need to see
evidence of when that is documented.

230
00:14:27.100 --> 00:14:31.080
And, also, we need to see evidence of
the fact that a decision was made and

231
00:14:31.080 --> 00:14:33.120
it was an informed decision.

232
00:14:33.120 --> 00:14:37.320
So we need to see evidence of
guidance on that decision, as well,

233
00:14:37.320 --> 00:14:41.630
and not just the fact that we
just closed the problem record.

234
00:14:41.630 --> 00:14:43.450
Obviously, you don't
just want to see that,

235
00:14:43.450 --> 00:14:47.200
we also want to see
the problem management.

236
00:14:47.200 --> 00:14:50.470
They are responsible for
the known error databases, so

237
00:14:50.470 --> 00:14:55.560
we want to see that known
error databases are in use.

238
00:14:55.560 --> 00:14:59.830
And that we're providing
information on known errors

239
00:14:59.830 --> 00:15:04.080
to both the incident management
process and service request process.

240
00:15:04.080 --> 00:15:09.360
So I want to see evidence of those known
errors and that known error database.

241
00:15:09.360 --> 00:15:13.900
And I'm always going to ask the question,
show me, show me that evidence.

242
00:15:15.210 --> 00:15:16.830
So at this point in time now,

243
00:15:16.830 --> 00:15:20.500
we've actually completed
our resolution processes.

244
00:15:20.500 --> 00:15:23.390
And when we come back,
in our next episode,

245
00:15:23.390 --> 00:15:28.230
we're going to take a look at clause nine,
which are our control processes.

246
00:15:28.230 --> 00:15:32.080
>> All right Jo, well thank you for your
time, and thank you for your time as well.

247
00:15:32.080 --> 00:15:34.050
But stay tuned we have more
information headed your way.

248
00:15:34.050 --> 00:15:36.190
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

249
00:15:36.190 --> 00:15:37.640
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

250
00:15:37.640 --> 00:15:38.415
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

251
00:15:38.415 --> 00:15:41.171
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

252
00:15:41.171 --> 00:15:47.118
[MUSIC]

253
00:15:47.118 --> 00:15:50.248
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo explain how the control processes: configuration management, change management, release and deployment management intact within an organization. They cover important terms such as configuration baseline, configuration item, CMDB, and request for change (RFC). In addition to breaking down these elements they also discus how configuration management intent.
episodes.title: Clause 9 - Control Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:02.583
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.583 --> 00:00:06.556
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.556 --> 00:00:08.373
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.373 --> 00:00:12.018
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.018 --> 00:00:18.199
>> Welcome back to your ISO/IEC
20000:2011 Foundation series.

6
00:00:18.199 --> 00:00:20.200
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:23.121
In this episode,
we'll be taking a look at Clause 9,

8
00:00:23.121 --> 00:00:25.225
specifically controlled processes.

9
00:00:25.225 --> 00:00:28.920
And who better to explain that
topic than ISO expert, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:28.920 --> 00:00:30.010
Thanks for joining us today, Jo.

11
00:00:31.050 --> 00:00:32.408
>> Thank you for having me, Cherokee.

12
00:00:32.408 --> 00:00:35.690
I can think of plenty of people better
to explain to be perfectly honest.

13
00:00:35.690 --> 00:00:36.714
>> [LAUGH] No, that's not true.

14
00:00:36.714 --> 00:00:39.136
>> [LAUGH] How are you this morning,
anyway?

15
00:00:39.136 --> 00:00:40.461
>> I'm good thank you for asking.

16
00:00:40.461 --> 00:00:42.689
So we've been moving right along here,

17
00:00:42.689 --> 00:00:46.693
looking at our different clauses when
we talk about control processes.

18
00:00:46.693 --> 00:00:48.388
What are we looking at here, Jo?

19
00:00:48.388 --> 00:00:50.235
>> Okay,
well we're looking at specifically.

20
00:00:50.235 --> 00:00:53.499
We're looking at change management,
we're looking at release and

21
00:00:53.499 --> 00:00:57.168
deployment management, and
we're looking at configuration management.

22
00:00:57.168 --> 00:01:01.453
Because these processes, if we take a look
at our service management system diagram,

23
00:01:01.453 --> 00:01:04.345
you'll see that these processes
sit right in the middle.

24
00:01:04.345 --> 00:01:09.415
These are our control processes, and we
call them our control processes because,

25
00:01:09.415 --> 00:01:14.250
these processes obviously have
relationships to every other process.

26
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:19.400
These processes affect every other
process and these processes, well,

27
00:01:19.400 --> 00:01:22.500
certainly when we look at
configuration management for instance.

28
00:01:22.500 --> 00:01:27.905
Configuration management has the
foundation for all of the other processes

29
00:01:27.905 --> 00:01:32.910
cuz configuration management stores all of
our information about all of our services.

30
00:01:32.910 --> 00:01:36.229
Now one of the things that you'll need
to do is to be able to demonstrate

31
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:41.940
at audit level that you have relationships
in place between your processes.

32
00:01:41.940 --> 00:01:45.550
And so configuration management is a very,

33
00:01:45.550 --> 00:01:48.870
very important process to demonstrate
those relationships through.

34
00:01:50.175 --> 00:01:54.485
One thing that I would recommend when
we're talking about relationships is that

35
00:01:54.485 --> 00:01:59.271
we or you, [LAUGH] Not we,
you compile a relationship diagram that

36
00:01:59.271 --> 00:02:02.884
will certainly help you to
articulate the relationships.

37
00:02:02.884 --> 00:02:06.285
And by that, the easiest way to do this.

38
00:02:06.285 --> 00:02:09.673
And I say the easiest way because I've
shown Cherokee an example of some

39
00:02:09.673 --> 00:02:13.190
relationship diagrams and
they didn't look anything but easy, right?

40
00:02:13.190 --> 00:02:16.599
>> As long as I'm not sitting over here
with like some crayons and stash paper.

41
00:02:16.599 --> 00:02:19.440
I think we'll be okay, but
yeah what's the recommendation?

42
00:02:19.440 --> 00:02:23.099
>> Yeah, I mean the last time I did a
relationship diagram which was a few weeks

43
00:02:23.099 --> 00:02:24.430
ago by the client.

44
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:30.300
We ended up using seven white
boards just the seven as so-

45
00:02:30.300 --> 00:02:32.072
>> There was a lot of information Jo.

46
00:02:32.072 --> 00:02:35.289
>> There was a lot of information
there you're right and so

47
00:02:35.289 --> 00:02:38.986
what I would recommend for
you is that for every single process,

48
00:02:38.986 --> 00:02:41.905
you detail the outputs for
every single process.

49
00:02:41.905 --> 00:02:48.039
So, an output obviously is something
tangible, what comes out of that process.

50
00:02:48.039 --> 00:02:51.986
So for instance if we're talking
about design and transition,

51
00:02:51.986 --> 00:02:55.910
then we would look for
a design plan, a design package.

52
00:02:55.910 --> 00:03:00.990
Now we detail that design package and
then what you need to do is, for

53
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:05.998
that one output, alone look at all
of the inputs into that output.

54
00:03:05.998 --> 00:03:10.488
So look at everything that
contributes to that design package.

55
00:03:10.488 --> 00:03:14.219
Well, when you think about this,
everything that contributes includes your

56
00:03:14.219 --> 00:03:18.188
service level targets, your hours of
operation, your service level agreement.

57
00:03:18.188 --> 00:03:24.524
All of your business requirements,
your project plans, your timescales,

58
00:03:24.524 --> 00:03:29.504
your vacation or holiday schedules,
your training needs.

59
00:03:29.504 --> 00:03:34.405
When you think about it, the inputs
into the service design package,

60
00:03:34.405 --> 00:03:37.656
well inputs could be 100, 200 inputs.

61
00:03:37.656 --> 00:03:40.620
And then think about where
those inputs come from.

62
00:03:40.620 --> 00:03:43.743
And then you also then need
to think about, right, okay.

63
00:03:43.743 --> 00:03:46.760
Well what's included in
the service design package?

64
00:03:46.760 --> 00:03:50.570
In other words, what do you present
from the service design package and

65
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:52.750
who uses that?

66
00:03:52.750 --> 00:03:55.465
So that would be our outputs or

67
00:03:55.465 --> 00:04:00.796
our relationship from that output,
the design package.

68
00:04:00.796 --> 00:04:03.190
So who uses that design package?

69
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:05.760
Well, the design package is
used by change management.

70
00:04:05.760 --> 00:04:09.941
It's used by release and deployment
management, and they use certain elements.

71
00:04:09.941 --> 00:04:14.324
So we've just looked at one specific
output there, and I have already mentioned

72
00:04:14.324 --> 00:04:18.460
probably about 20 different relationships
just in the last few seconds.

73
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:24.861
So like I said, last time I did a full
service management relationship diagram

74
00:04:24.861 --> 00:04:29.971
with somebody within their organization,
we used up seven whiteboards.

75
00:04:29.971 --> 00:04:34.535
And I did actually take photos of them
because we all have cell phones now and

76
00:04:34.535 --> 00:04:35.920
I took photos of them.

77
00:04:35.920 --> 00:04:40.723
And I was showing them to Cherokee
just before this session actually.

78
00:04:40.723 --> 00:04:43.010
And it looked like a spider crawled
across the board, didn't it?

79
00:04:43.010 --> 00:04:45.232
>> It did, but
you did have some color coding so

80
00:04:45.232 --> 00:04:47.164
that made it easier to understand so.

81
00:04:47.164 --> 00:04:47.735
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

82
00:04:47.735 --> 00:04:50.696
I mean you know you could put
color coding in there etc.

83
00:04:50.696 --> 00:04:54.657
But one thing that you have to do,
is you have to be able to articulate and

84
00:04:54.657 --> 00:04:58.102
demonstrate to the auditor that
these relationships exist.

85
00:04:58.102 --> 00:05:01.582
And that you understand that
these relationships exist.

86
00:05:01.582 --> 00:05:06.468
So when you're pulling together,
for example, a design package,

87
00:05:06.468 --> 00:05:10.765
then I want to see exactly what
make up that design package and

88
00:05:10.765 --> 00:05:14.148
exactly where those
elements are coming from.

89
00:05:14.148 --> 00:05:19.320
So I want to see that maybe the vacation
schedule is coming from HR and

90
00:05:19.320 --> 00:05:22.600
I actually want to see that relationship.

91
00:05:22.600 --> 00:05:24.549
I want to see evidence
of that relationship.

92
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:28.757
I want to see that the Gantt chart or

93
00:05:28.757 --> 00:05:32.908
the timeline is coming directly
from project management.

94
00:05:32.908 --> 00:05:37.166
And I want to see that relationship, so
I want to see the output, and I want

95
00:05:37.166 --> 00:05:41.997
to see where that relationship's coming

00:25:18.352 --> 00:25:24.816
You can not exclude any of those
requirements that are in Clauses 4 to 9.

399
00:25:24.816 --> 00:25:25.950
You can't do that.

400
00:25:27.220 --> 00:25:32.423
Part 1 is not a standard for
products, or services, or for

401
00:25:32.423 --> 00:25:38.933
the organization, but Part 1 is
everything that you have to achieve.

402
00:25:38.933 --> 00:25:42.681
And I like the interesting point there
that says that you do not need to own

403
00:25:42.681 --> 00:25:43.860
the infrastructure.

404
00:25:43.860 --> 00:25:47.235
The technology doesn't have to be yours.

405
00:25:47.235 --> 00:25:52.313
You can still achieve ISO 20000,
because what we're auditing against,

406
00:25:52.313 --> 00:25:57.050
we are auditing against your ability
to manage the infrastructure.

407
00:25:57.050 --> 00:26:00.510
We are not auditing
the infrastructure itself.

408
00:26:02.710 --> 00:26:06.410
But these requirements, well,
you have to meet them all.

409
00:26:06.410 --> 00:26:11.558
In order to pass the order you have to
meet them all, and the first thing that

410
00:26:11.558 --> 00:26:16.458
you have to do is, you have to set
a scope, and your scope is the scope for

411
00:26:16.458 --> 00:26:22.178
the actual audit itself, in other words
what processes you're going to include,

412
00:26:22.178 --> 00:26:26.918
what documentation you're going
to include, what about skills and

413
00:26:26.918 --> 00:26:31.450
training of stuff, don't forget,
they're included as well.

414
00:26:31.450 --> 00:26:36.773
Your organization has
to be a legal entity.

415
00:26:36.773 --> 00:26:42.439
So in other words, you have to have
a registered company, and whatever country

416
00:26:42.439 --> 00:26:47.767
you are located in you have to have
a registered company, and a certificate

417
00:26:47.767 --> 00:26:53.330
will not be awarded to anybody that
are formed from lots of legal entities.

418
00:26:53.330 --> 00:26:55.260
So a partnership, for instance,

419
00:26:55.260 --> 00:26:59.970
you are not going to be awarded
a certificate across a partnership.

420
00:26:59.970 --> 00:27:04.580
The certificate will be
awarded to one legal entity.

421
00:27:04.580 --> 00:27:09.567
Even though maybe the processes
themselves are spread across to

422
00:27:09.567 --> 00:27:14.737
organizations, nevertheless,
no that's not going to happen,

423
00:27:14.737 --> 00:27:19.279
it's going to be awarded to just one,
not to both of them.

424
00:27:19.279 --> 00:27:24.216
That's something that's worth bearing in
mind, because when we talk about software

425
00:27:24.216 --> 00:27:28.609
as a service, and when we talk about
the fact that a lot of organizations now,

426
00:27:28.609 --> 00:27:33.479
we'll outsource, and we'll use one service
provider to provide us with one thing,

427
00:27:33.479 --> 00:27:38.077
and somebody else to provide us with
something else, then if you're looking for

428
00:27:38.077 --> 00:27:41.036
ISO 20000 accreditation-
>> You can't share that.

429
00:27:41.036 --> 00:27:42.519
>> You can't share it with anybody, no.

430
00:27:42.519 --> 00:27:43.460
That's yours.

431
00:27:43.460 --> 00:27:45.370
You cannot share it with anyone at all.

432
00:27:46.850 --> 00:27:50.930
In terms of the governance of
the processes for form clause 4,

433
00:27:50.930 --> 00:27:53.830
well, you have to ensure,

434
00:27:53.830 --> 00:27:57.570
when we look at third parties, and
just while we're talking about this,

435
00:27:57.570 --> 00:28:02.870
when we look at third parties, if a third
party were outsourcing something and

436
00:28:02.870 --> 00:28:05.560
they're providing a service for
us, then we own that.

437
00:28:05.560 --> 00:28:09.220
We own that process, and we own that
service, and we own the processes and

438
00:28:09.220 --> 00:28:13.410
the policies to manage that, and
that's what you will be audited against.

439
00:28:13.410 --> 00:28:17.890
So that means that you are responsible for
what they're doing, and if what they're

440
00:28:17.890 --> 00:28:24.400
producing is not conformant to ISO 20000,
then you won't achieve your audit.

441
00:28:24.400 --> 00:28:25.860
It's as simple as that.

442
00:28:25.860 --> 00:28:30.495
So you have to make sure that what
they're doing is going to allow you to

443
00:28:30.495 --> 00:28:35.604
achieve ISO 20000, because if what
you're doing isn't going to allow

444
00:28:35.604 --> 00:28:40.557
you to achieve ISO 20,000 leave it
to nonconformity that it's quite

445
00:28:40.557 --> 00:28:45.615
simply a nonconformity, and
you're not going to achieve ISO 20000.

446
00:28:45.615 --> 00:28:49.060
So just before we start to
take a look at evidence, and

447
00:28:49.060 --> 00:28:52.351
we're going to take a look
at that in our next show,

448
00:28:52.351 --> 00:28:57.787
we're just going to call that a wrap for
this particular show, and we'll carry on,

449
00:28:57.787 --> 00:29:01.945
and look in at all the evidence
that you need in our next episode.

450
00:29:01.945 --> 00:29:04.442
>> All right, and just like Jo said,
looks like that's a wrap.

451
00:29:04.442 --> 00:29:06.259
So, thank you for joining us here.

452
00:29:06.259 --> 00:29:08.648
Let's stay tuned,
we're not finished quite yet.

453
00:29:08.648 --> 00:29:10.067
For this show, we'll sign out.

454
00:29:10.067 --> 00:29:11.722
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

455
00:29:11.722 --> 00:29:12.484
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

456
00:29:12.484 --> 00:29:14.493
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

457
00:29:14.493 --> 00:29:20.392
[MUSIC]

458
00:29:20.392 --> 00:29:23.560
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo continue to walk through the audit and certification process to help you be fully prepared for the process.
episodes.title: Audits and Certification Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:02.509
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.509 --> 00:00:07.173
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.173 --> 00:00:08.342
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.342 --> 00:00:11.975
>> You are watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.975 --> 00:00:17.425
>> Welcome back to your ISO/IEC
20000 2011 Foundation Series.

6
00:00:17.425 --> 00:00:19.910
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:19.910 --> 00:00:24.165
In the last episode we were looking at the
auditing and certification process, and

8
00:00:24.165 --> 00:00:25.823
we're not quite finished yet.

9
00:00:25.823 --> 00:00:29.760
So back in the studio with us today
we have ISO expert Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:31.360
Thanks for joining us Jo.

11
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:33.080
>> It's great to be here Cherokee,
how are you?

12
00:00:33.080 --> 00:00:35.827
>> I am doing excellent thank you for
asking.

13
00:00:35.827 --> 00:00:39.623
We started going through that
process of what to expect.

14
00:00:39.623 --> 00:00:42.146
Well, we had already gone
through all the clauses, and

15
00:00:42.146 --> 00:00:45.110
we have that good understanding now,
but what's left to cover?

16
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:49.433
>> Really what we're covering
in this particular section,

17
00:00:49.433 --> 00:00:51.966
this is just a Part 2 of
our previous episode.

18
00:00:51.966 --> 00:00:56.723
And we're just carrying on with
the exact audit process, really,

19
00:00:56.723 --> 00:00:59.904
and exactly what to
expect during the audit.

20
00:00:59.904 --> 00:01:04.168
We've already, as you've seen, gone
through in previous episode what clauses

21
00:01:04.168 --> 00:01:07.900
we need to cover, and also what
documentation that we need to produce.

22
00:01:07.900 --> 00:01:12.900
And so here we're just having, well,
kind of a refresher, but more importantly

23
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:17.340
this is just an overview of what
the auditor is going to ask of you.

24
00:01:17.340 --> 00:01:21.920
And how the process is going to go,
what's gonna happen at the end of it.

25
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:26.264
So in Part 1, we just looked
at the frequency of audits and

26
00:01:26.264 --> 00:01:28.401
who can get to do your audit.

27
00:01:28.401 --> 00:01:33.874
And well the relevance of bringing in
an external consultant to help you.

28
00:01:33.874 --> 00:01:38.640
Certainly the first time that you try, or
once you've made the decision to try and

29
00:01:38.640 --> 00:01:40.174
achieve ISO 20000.

30
00:01:40.174 --> 00:01:44.961
And so now we're just gonna look a little
bit more in depth at the evidence

31
00:01:44.961 --> 00:01:46.463
that you can provide.

32
00:01:46.463 --> 00:01:50.986
What can be submitted and what can't
be submitted, and also the scope,

33
00:01:50.986 --> 00:01:53.210
etc of the actual audit itself.

34
00:01:53.210 --> 00:01:54.744
>> All right, sounds like a plan.

35
00:01:54.744 --> 00:01:56.294
>> Right, well then well we better get

36
00:01:56.294 --> 00:01:57.023
going then say-

37
00:01:57.023 --> 00:01:58.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right.

38
00:01:58.310 --> 00:02:02.450
>> That's it, sounds like a plan
all right well then, [LAUGH] Well,

39
00:02:02.450 --> 00:02:07.590
let's take a look then at our Part 1 then,
the evidence then here for Part 1.

40
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:11.300
So we've been through, in previous
sessions we've been through all of

41
00:02:11.300 --> 00:02:16.020
the mandatory requirements which is the,
you shall produce this and

42
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:18.680
you want to see evidence of relationships,
etc.

43
00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:21.050
So what do I want to see?

44
00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:23.610
Well, generically for
every single process,

45
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:28.310
we've got to see accountability for
each process.

46
00:02:28.310 --> 00:02:31.360
And this is evidence required for
conformity to Clause 4,

47
00:02:31.360 --> 00:02:34.960
now if you remember Clause 4,
was the service management system.

48
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:40.144
A service management system
was all about the policies and

49
00:02:40.144 --> 00:02:43.644
processes, and the management of IT.

50
00:02:43.644 --> 00:02:45.020
So what does this really mean?

51
00:02:45.020 --> 00:02:50.723
Well, what it means is that every
process has to have a process owner.

52
00:02:50.723 --> 00:02:53.624
Every process has to be documented,

53
00:02:53.624 --> 00:02:58.410
every process has to be
subject to version control.

54
00:02:58.410 --> 00:03:02.820
Every process has to be subject
to continual improvement.

55
00:03:04.000 --> 00:03:05.090
What does that actually mean?

56
00:03:06.790 --> 00:03:10.769
Well, first a start,
I don't care what you call your processes.

57
00:03:12.100 --> 00:03:16.949
But, I do care that you've got processes
that cover things like incident and

58
00:03:16.949 --> 00:03:21.813
problem management and that you understand
the difference between the two.

59
00:03:21.813 --> 00:03:25.459
I do care that you have
a process that covers

60
00:03:25.459 --> 00:03:30.438
the change of anything to do
with your IT infrastructure.

61
00:03:30.438 --> 00:03:34.596
I do care that you have a process to
come about configuration management and

62
00:03:34.596 --> 00:03:38.410
I do care that you have service
level management in place.

63
00:03:38.410 --> 00:03:42.495
What you call those
processes I don't care.

64
00:03:42.495 --> 00:03:46.580
I do care that you have an owner
that's defined for each process.

65
00:03:46.580 --> 00:03:52.520
So in the process documentation,
I want to see a revision history.

66
00:03:52.520 --> 00:03:57.227
I'm probably going to ask to see all
the versions of the processes is two.

67
00:03:57.227 --> 00:04:01.159
I'm gonna want to see that
you have a process owner, and

68
00:04:01.159 --> 00:04:06.098
that processor is documented within
the process documentation, and

69
00:04:06.098 --> 00:04:11.470
I might even want to speak with that
process owner each individual process.

70
00:04:12.680 --> 00:04:16.983
I'm going to want to see that
part of your process details what

71
00:04:16.983 --> 00:04:21.221
to do when you've identified
an improvement opportunity.

72
00:04:21.221 --> 00:04:25.710
I'm going to ask to see
specific procedures to do with

73
00:04:25.710 --> 00:04:28.600
certain process activities.

74
00:04:28.600 --> 00:04:32.927
So I might ask to see work instructions.

75
00:04:32.927 --> 00:04:39.793
What I need to see is all of the evidence
to do with all of the processes that tells

76
00:04:39.793 --> 00:04:47.040
me whether a process as an owner that
tells me whether a process has activity.

77
00:04:47.040 --> 00:04:52.180
It tells me that you understand
the defined inputs to a process and

78
00:04:52.180 --> 00:04:57.740
you understand what outputs you expect
from a process, and that you know

79
00:04:57.740 --> 00:05:02.890
what to do in a process doesn't quite turn
out the way that you expected it to do.

80
00:05:04.100 --> 00:05:08.570
I'm also looking for
evidence that processes are followed.

81
00:05:08.570 --> 00:05:13.900
So again I'm looking for
evidence what to do in an exception,

82
00:05:13.900 --> 00:05:17.870
what to do when somebody doesn't
follow the changed management process.

83
00:05:17.870 --> 00:05:22.234
Now remember the things that we talked
about earlier on about making the decision

84
00:05:22.234 --> 00:05:23.851
for change management as to.

85
00:05:23.851 --> 00:05:28.239
Do we allow the service test update
configuration management system or

86
00:05:28.239 --> 00:05:32.270
do we insist that it goes through
the change management process?

87
00:05:33.290 --> 00:05:36.745
All of those decisions, there have to be
documents it's part of the policies and

88
00:05:36.745 --> 00:05:40.965
the guidances for IT service management.

89
00:05:40.965 --> 00:05:45.705
So I want to make sure that we've got
all of that control documented and

90
00:05:45.705 --> 00:05:49.995
that you're able to prioritize
not only process improvements but

91
00:05:49.995 --> 00:05:52.695
prioritize within the processes
themselves as well.

92
00:05:53.695 --> 00:05:57.490
So, we've seen in service
level management that we have

93
00:05:57.490 --> 00:06:02.520
prioritization tables that are contained
within the service level agreement.

94
00:06:02.520 --> 00:06:07.716
And those prioritization tables apply to
incidents, and they apply to changes,

95
00:06:07.716 --> 00:06:12.475
and they apply to problems, and
they apply to requests, etc, etc, etc.

96
00:06:12.475 --> 00:06:17.173
However, it's not impossible that
you will get a number of priority

97
00:06:17.173 --> 00:06:22.160
three incidents opened at the same time,
so how do you prioritize?

98
00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:26.564
Well, I'd expect you, if they're all
a priority three, I would expect you to

99
00:06:26.564 --> 00:06:30.201
prioritize them based on time,
the one that was opened soonest.

100
00:06:30.201 --> 00:06:31.787
But you might not do that, so

101
00:06:31.787 --> 00:06:35.960
I want to see evidence of how you
actually prioritize your incidents.

102
00:06:35.960 --> 00:06:38.780
>> So as long as there is some kind
of triage methodology in place.

103
00:06:38.780 --> 00:06:43.479
Like, however many people it's affecting
as far as being out of production, and

104
00:06:43.479 --> 00:06:44.100
so forth.

105
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:47.316
>> Yes, but it's not enough for
you to tell me that yes,

106
00:06:47.316 --> 00:06:51.000
it's okay because Justin
knows what he's doing.

107
00:06:51.000 --> 00:06:53.230
Well for start Justin doesn't
know what he's doing but anyway.

108
00:06:53.230 --> 00:06:54.037
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

109
00:06:54.037 --> 00:06:54.841
>> Don't tell him that.

110
00:06:54.841 --> 00:06:59.160
>> [LAUGH] No no okay yes we just
had this discussion with him.

111
00:06:59.160 --> 00:07:00.750
But it's not enough for you to say to me,

112
00:07:00.750 --> 00:07:02.610
no that's okay Justin
knows what he's doing.

113
00:07:02.610 --> 00:07:06.710
I want to see where it's documented,
because what if Justin wasn't around and

114
00:07:06.710 --> 00:07:08.640
Ronnie had to do something that day.

115
00:07:08.640 --> 00:07:12.049
Ronnie wouldn't know what to do, and
he wouldn't know how to prioritize.

116
00:07:12.049 --> 00:07:15.957
So this evidence,
it's got to be documentary evidence.

117
00:07:15.957 --> 00:07:22.180
And I know that I said time and time
again, show me, but you have to see this.

118
00:07:22.180 --> 00:07:26.440
It has to be shown,
it has to be given to the auditor,

119
00:07:26.440 --> 00:07:28.300
we have to have that documentary evidence.

120
00:07:28.300 --> 00:07:33.620
Now you can have it within a process for
your tool and that's okay.

121
00:07:33.620 --> 00:07:37.390
But at some point in time,
you must have configured your tool.

122
00:07:37.390 --> 00:07:40.020
I want to see the configuration
of your tool then.

123
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:44.590
If it's all contained in the tool and
the tool is automating this,

124
00:07:44.590 --> 00:07:49.418
there still has to be a documented
process that the tool will perform.

125
00:07:49.418 --> 00:07:54.397
So even where it's automated even where
you've got it all facilitating this,

126
00:07:54.397 --> 00:07:57.232
there still has to be
documentary evidence.

127
00:07:57.232 --> 00:08:01.451
And you can have additional evidence
such as your catalogue of services

128
00:08:01.451 --> 00:08:05.815
The individual service level agreements
that contain the service levels

129
00:08:05.815 --> 00:08:06.670
targets etc.

130
00:08:07.810 --> 00:08:13.340
External documents such as documents for
the use of the tool.

131
00:08:13.340 --> 00:08:18.220
Documents that will tell me what specific
processes are and specific plans, and

132
00:08:18.220 --> 00:08:21.230
specific procedures and work instructions.

133
00:08:21.230 --> 00:08:24.740
I want to see documentation
that shows me the integration.

134
00:08:25.990 --> 00:08:28.668
So, for instance,
a service level agreement.

135
00:08:28.668 --> 00:08:32.237
A service level agreement is a document
that our customers sign, yes?

136
00:08:32.237 --> 00:08:35.852
It's an agreement between IT and
the service provider.

137
00:08:37.311 --> 00:08:39.541
But what do with that
service level document?

138
00:08:39.541 --> 00:08:45.532
Is it a document that we keep in our
document repository management system?

139
00:08:45.532 --> 00:08:50.783
Is it a document that we put into
SharePoint, or is it actually a document

140
00:08:50.783 --> 00:08:56.960
that we keep in SharePoint and a record
that we create in our core logging tool?

141
00:08:56.960 --> 00:09:02.380
So that when we create a record that
record, that service level record contains

142
00:09:02.380 --> 00:09:08.315
all of the operational hours,
the release windows, the change freezes.

143
00:09:08.315 --> 00:09:12.440
That contains the target resolution for

144
00:09:12.440 --> 00:09:18.000
priorities one sort of priorities four or
five or whatever you might call for

145
00:09:18.000 --> 00:09:22.190
incident management, the target
resolution times, or response times.

146
00:09:22.190 --> 00:09:25.781
The problem management and
the target resolution times or

147
00:09:25.781 --> 00:09:29.084
implementation times would
change management etc.

148
00:09:29.084 --> 00:09:34.929
Because you see if you imput this into the
tool, then its automatically then related

149
00:09:34.929 --> 00:09:40.050
to the incidents, and the problems,
and the changes, and the request.

150
00:09:41.470 --> 00:09:45.180
So how is your service
level management perform?

151
00:09:45.180 --> 00:09:48.236
Is it performed using just the document,
or

152
00:09:48.236 --> 00:09:52.294
is it actually performed to
manage using the tool itself?

153
00:09:52.294 --> 00:09:54.250
That's the supplementary information.

154
00:09:54.250 --> 00:09:57.300
That's the evidence that I want to see.

155
00:09:57.300 --> 00:09:59.230
That's what we mean by show me.

156
00:10:01.030 --> 00:10:02.830
Just because you've gone and

157
00:10:02.830 --> 00:10:08.024
bought a tool off the shelf doesn't mean
that you have complied with ISO 20000.

158
00:10:08.024 --> 00:10:12.587
And I know that I've said this in
the past when it comes to ITIL, but

159
00:10:12.587 --> 00:10:18.473
there's no such thing as ITIL compliant,
because ITIL is well, it's a framework.

160
00:10:18.473 --> 00:10:19.081
>> A framework.

161
00:10:19.081 --> 00:10:23.360
>> Yeah, that you will adapt
to suit your environment.

162
00:10:23.360 --> 00:10:28.045
There is such a thing

00:08:31.310 --> 00:08:36.914
Does it meet the requirements
of the certification,

132
00:08:36.914 --> 00:08:41.720
and are there any nonconformities here?

133
00:08:41.720 --> 00:08:46.840
These nonconformity the areas where
we don't meet the requirements,

134
00:08:46.840 --> 00:08:49.300
we don't meet the scope necessarily,

135
00:08:49.300 --> 00:08:52.500
well these nonconformities
are where we have to improve.

136
00:08:53.760 --> 00:08:55.220
And then we prepare for

137
00:08:55.220 --> 00:09:00.040
a certification in Phase 1 and
that's by doing our pre-assessment audit.

138
00:09:00.040 --> 00:09:01.970
So our Phase 1 audit and

139
00:09:01.970 --> 00:09:06.220
our second phase audit as well Which
is the final certification ordered.

140
00:09:06.220 --> 00:09:09.700
Now at this point in time, if you've
got somebody external, if you've got

141
00:09:09.700 --> 00:09:14.160
an external consultant in, then at this
point in time you're pre-assessment order.

142
00:09:14.160 --> 00:09:18.057
You'll already be aware of what
non-conformities you have.

143
00:09:18.057 --> 00:09:22.064
So I'd expect that once we get to this
point here, you should be aware of where

144
00:09:22.064 --> 00:09:26.194
you need to improve, and if in fact it's
really down to here, during Phase 3,

145
00:09:26.194 --> 00:09:28.830
where all of this should come out.

146
00:09:28.830 --> 00:09:32.746
If you don't have anybody
external helping you with this,

147
00:09:32.746 --> 00:09:37.619
then your internal audit at Phase 3,
they might not pick everything up.

148
00:09:37.619 --> 00:09:39.027
And just be aware of that,

149
00:09:39.027 --> 00:09:43.396
your pre-assessment audit may pick up
other things that you haven't noticed.

150
00:09:43.396 --> 00:09:47.469
And then we're moving to the end of
Phase 4 where you get your final

151
00:09:47.469 --> 00:09:48.939
certification audit.

152
00:09:48.939 --> 00:09:51.960
And that's where your
certificate will be awarded.

153
00:09:51.960 --> 00:09:55.889
And then at that point in time,
from there onwards what will happen is,

154
00:09:55.889 --> 00:09:58.835
you will have your surveillance
audits every year and

155
00:09:58.835 --> 00:10:01.797
then you will have your full
audit every three years.

156
00:10:03.751 --> 00:10:08.483
I've already mentioned in
a previous episode that tool set,

157
00:10:08.483 --> 00:10:11.761
they don't conform to ISO 20,000.

158
00:10:11.761 --> 00:10:16.959
They don't conform to ITIL either,
although if we look at

159
00:10:16.959 --> 00:10:22.474
the pink verify website,
then you will find a list of tools and

160
00:10:22.474 --> 00:10:27.591
whether they support the ITIL
best practice framework.

161
00:10:27.591 --> 00:10:32.380
And also what process is within the ITIL
best practice framework they support.

162
00:10:32.380 --> 00:10:37.070
You have to make the decision as to
how you want to select your tool, and

163
00:10:37.070 --> 00:10:40.070
we've already had this discussion
in our previous sessions.

164
00:10:40.070 --> 00:10:44.735
So you know that in our previous episode
we've spoken about this at length.

165
00:10:44.735 --> 00:10:47.508
You just need to make a decision,

166
00:10:47.508 --> 00:10:52.964
as to whether you want to bring in
somebody to write it all for you.

167
00:10:52.964 --> 00:10:55.048
Whether you want to buy
something off the shelf and

168
00:10:55.048 --> 00:10:56.830
how you want to implement it as well.

169
00:10:56.830 --> 00:11:01.091
Do you implement it module by module or
do want to try and

170
00:11:01.091 --> 00:11:04.623
implement everything
in a big bang fashion?

171
00:11:04.623 --> 00:11:09.821
Depends on the size of the organization
and quite frankly it depends on the amount

172
00:11:09.821 --> 00:11:15.040
of disruption that you are able to
accommodate within the organization.

173
00:11:15.040 --> 00:11:19.300
It can be a challenge doing it either way
because implementing in a phased manner,

174
00:11:19.300 --> 00:11:22.610
well that means that you're gonna
have some data on old data bases and

175
00:11:22.610 --> 00:11:26.905
some data on new data bases and
you have to think about migration, etc.

176
00:11:26.905 --> 00:11:32.025
Doing it in a big bang fashion and bring
everything in all once can be very costly,

177
00:11:32.025 --> 00:11:36.259
because you're talking about all
of the licenses, all upfront.

178
00:11:36.259 --> 00:11:40.614
But you also have to accommodate some
disruption where everybody tries to get

179
00:11:40.614 --> 00:11:45.103
used to and you call login system where
everybody is going to a training and where

180
00:11:45.103 --> 00:11:49.726
everybody is kind of running around a bit
like headless chickens, to be perfectly

181
00:11:49.726 --> 00:11:53.820
honest at the beginning, wondering
what on earth they should be doing.

182
00:11:55.140 --> 00:11:59.414
Whatever you do, your implementation
plan and your deployment plan and

183
00:11:59.414 --> 00:12:01.104
the processes themselves.

184
00:12:01.104 --> 00:12:05.878
Remember you configure the tool
to facilitate the processes,

185
00:12:05.878 --> 00:12:09.580
they should be in your
service management plan.

186
00:12:09.580 --> 00:12:13.542
They should be in your service management
system because you're going to be audited

187
00:12:13.542 --> 00:12:15.155
against those processes.

188
00:12:15.155 --> 00:12:18.505
You need that documentation so
why rewrite it?

189
00:12:18.505 --> 00:12:19.887
Why reinvent the wheel?

190
00:12:19.887 --> 00:12:22.101
That's certainly not efficient.

191
00:12:22.101 --> 00:12:27.219
If you're implementing a new tool to help
you, then simply write your processes

192
00:12:27.219 --> 00:12:32.760
down that you want to achieve and
there you go, version one of your process.

193
00:12:32.760 --> 00:12:37.494
You've got something to show
the auditor when the auditor says,

194
00:12:37.494 --> 00:12:41.463
show me well, there you go,
you can show them, okay?

195
00:12:41.463 --> 00:12:46.000
Remember, however you implement a tool,
and

196
00:12:46.000 --> 00:12:53.447
however you achieve your ISO 20000,
you have surveillance audits and

197
00:12:53.447 --> 00:12:57.653
you have another audit every three years.

198
00:12:57.653 --> 00:13:02.655
The auditor knows that in three years
things haven't remained the same,

199
00:13:02.655 --> 00:13:07.507
because we're in IT, and things
don't stay the same for three years.

200
00:13:07.507 --> 00:13:11.828
So the auditor is to going to want to
see evidence that things have moved, and

201
00:13:11.828 --> 00:13:15.515
things have improved and
things have changed over three years.

202
00:13:15.515 --> 00:13:18.647
Cuz you cannot tell me and
I don't believe you if you do,

203
00:13:18.647 --> 00:13:22.981
you can't tell me that three years have
elapsed from one audit to the next when

204
00:13:22.981 --> 00:13:25.267
you've not raised any change request.

205
00:13:25.267 --> 00:13:28.051
And you've not had any incidence,
and you've not had any problems and

206
00:13:28.051 --> 00:13:30.291
everything is exactly the same
as it was three years ago.

207
00:13:30.291 --> 00:13:33.746
>> You've got bigger problems than wanting
to pass an audit if that were the case.

208
00:13:33.746 --> 00:13:35.496
>> Right.
[LAUGH]

209
00:13:35.496 --> 00:13:35.996
>> [LAUGH]

210
00:13:35.996 --> 00:13:37.179
>> Yes a lot bigger problems,

211
00:13:37.179 --> 00:13:38.983
like the fact that you have no customers.

212
00:13:38.983 --> 00:13:40.395
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

213
00:13:40.395 --> 00:13:42.179
>> That's a bigger problem.

214
00:13:42.179 --> 00:13:44.296
So, things will have changed over

215
00:13:44.296 --> 00:13:49.041
the three years and don't try and
convince the auditors that they haven't,

216
00:13:49.041 --> 00:13:51.110
all right.
We can see through that.

217
00:13:51.110 --> 00:13:56.100
So, we need to see evidence that you
have improved over those three years,

218
00:13:56.100 --> 00:13:59.210
we need to see the evidence that
you have made improvements.

219
00:13:59.210 --> 00:14:02.990
And that as things have changed,
as maybe new services have come

220
00:14:02.990 --> 00:14:07.120
online as the number of incidents is
increased or decreased the number

221
00:14:07.120 --> 00:14:12.108
of changes is increased or decreased, then
we want to see evidence of improvement.

222
00:14:12.108 --> 00:14:15.196
And we want to see a plan for
every single improvement.

223
00:14:15.196 --> 00:14:17.539
So, we want to see things
like CSI registers,

224
00:14:17.539 --> 00:14:21.670
we want to see that you're prioritizing
your improvement opportunities.

225
00:14:21.670 --> 00:14:25.923
And that when you're implementing
improvement opportunities

226
00:14:25.923 --> 00:14:29.789
that there's a plan behind that
we need to see all of that.

227
00:14:29.789 --> 00:14:34.850
Okay, so now we have reached the end
of our ISO 20000 course material,

228
00:14:34.850 --> 00:14:36.749
and so what's available for

229
00:14:36.749 --> 00:14:41.530
you in your downloadable material
are some refresher exercises.

230
00:14:41.530 --> 00:14:47.298
Just to refresh your memories on exactly
what we've covered throughout the class.

231
00:14:47.298 --> 00:14:51.677
You also have some sample
questions in a separate piece

232
00:14:51.677 --> 00:14:55.910
of downloadable material or
a separate format.

233
00:14:55.910 --> 00:15:01.010
So what I'd like you to do right now is,
I would like you to download the sample

234
00:15:01.010 --> 00:15:06.220
questions, and I would like you
to take those sample questions.

235
00:15:06.220 --> 00:15:10.688
And if you come back in a later session
we will go over the sample questions with

236
00:15:10.688 --> 00:15:13.740
you, there're only ten
sample questions for you.

237
00:15:13.740 --> 00:15:16.255
And so come back,
join us in a later session and

238
00:15:16.255 --> 00:15:19.932
we will actually go over those
sample questions, and we'll go over

239
00:15:19.932 --> 00:15:24.740
a little bit more information about the
actual exam for an ISO 20000 foundation.

240
00:15:24.740 --> 00:15:26.400
>> All right, well you heard it.

241
00:15:26.400 --> 00:15:28.260
You don't wanna miss
those sample questions,

242
00:15:28.260 --> 00:15:30.850
because that might give
you an insight into what,

243
00:15:30.850 --> 00:15:35.100
as to what to expect moving forward here
and prepping for that certification.

244
00:15:35.100 --> 00:15:37.310
But, for this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

245
00:15:37.310 --> 00:15:38.910
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

246
00:15:38.910 --> 00:15:39.705
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

247
00:15:39.705 --> 00:15:41.410
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

248
00:15:41.410 --> 00:15:48.350
[MUSIC]

249
00:15:48.350 --> 00:15:50.922
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

3

4
00:00:10.707 --> 00:00:16.884
>> Welcome back to your ISO/IEC
20000:2011 Foundation series.

5
00:00:16.884 --> 00:00:19.860
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.860 --> 00:00:22.980
In this episode,
we'll be taking a look at an exam review.

7
00:00:22.980 --> 00:00:24.599
And you guessed it, Mrs.

00:00:24.599 --> 00:00:28.500
Jo Peacock has some surprise,
like a pop quiz for us here.

9
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:32.110
So we can only imagine how this is
going to go, I'm pretty excited.

10
00:00:32.110 --> 00:00:35.921
And you should be too because you'll
probably be laughing at my detriment

11
00:00:35.921 --> 00:00:36.604
here [LAUGH].

12
00:00:36.604 --> 00:00:38.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, Jo?

13
00:00:38.130 --> 00:00:41.148
[LAUGH]
>> I'm not saying a word, nothing.

14
00:00:41.148 --> 00:00:45.249
>> All right, so we do have some questions
available that we are gonna cover here and

15
00:00:45.249 --> 00:00:48.060
just kinda get in that mindset and
that mentality.

16
00:00:48.060 --> 00:00:50.190
Hey, I'm getting ready for this exam.

17
00:00:50.190 --> 00:00:51.970
What should I expect, right?

18
00:00:51.970 --> 00:00:55.150
>> Right, well, first of all, I mean,
she's being really eager right now.

00:00:55.150 --> 00:00:57.705
She's very enthusiastic,

20

For those of you that have sat your ITIL
Foundation exam, then you will find your

23
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:14.480
ISO 20000 exam to be in a very,
very similar format.

24
00:01:14.480 --> 00:01:18.618
You will have a one hour to complete

25
00:01:18.618 --> 00:01:23.346
a 40 question multiple choice test.

26
00:01:23.346 --> 00:01:28.810
You'll need to get 26 out of 40 in
order to pass, and you will take

27
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:35.190
your exam in exactly the same way that
you would take your ITIL Foundation exam.

28
00:01:35.190 --> 00:01:38.862
So in this instance then,
what you will do is,

00:01:38.862 --> 00:01:44.901

30
00:01:44.901 --> 00:01:50.327
And the peoplecert organization,

00:01:50.327 --> 00:01:55.228
